questions.text: An alcoholic patient presents with palpitations, dizziness, and syncopal attacks. On examination, irregularly irregular pulse is seen. What will be seen on JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Absent a wave:

Explanation:

The patient’s irregularly irregular pulse suggests atrial fibrillation (AF), which is common in chronic alcoholics (so-called holiday heart syndrome). In AF, the atria do not contract effectively → no coordinated atrial systole → no a wave is produced in the jugular venous pulse (JVP). Therefore, the finding will be absent a wave.

Jugular Venous Pulse (JVP) reflects right atrial pressure changes during the cardiac cycle.

  • The a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (just before S1).
  • In AF, there is complete loss of organized atrial contraction → a wave disappears.
  • Chronic alcoholics are prone to AF due to atrial dilation, electrolyte imbalance, and direct myocardial effects.

Atrial fibrillation:

Feature

Details

ECG

Irregularly irregular RR intervals, absent P waves, fibrillatory baseline

Causes

Hypertension, valvular heart disease (esp. mitral), alcohol (holiday heart), thyrotoxicosis

Complications

Stroke, heart failure, tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy

Management

Rate control (β-blockers, CCBs), rhythm control (amiodarone, cardioversion), anticoagulation (CHA₂DS₂-VASc score)

JVP Waveform:

  • Positive waves in JVP:
    • a, c and v
    • a wave - Atrium Contraction (Lat Rapid Filling Phase)
    • c wave - Cusp bulging (tricuspid valve cusp bulging towards the atrium) v wave - Venous return
  • Negative waves in JVP:
    • x wave - Atrium relaxation
    • x' wave - Tricuspid valve pulling towards the ventricle
    • y descend - Opening of tricuspid valve

JVP finding

Cause

Absent a wave

Atrial fibrillation

Large a wave

Tricuspid stenosis, pulmonary hypertension

Cannon a wave

Complete heart block, VT (atria contracting against closed tricuspid valve)

Steep y descent

Constrictive pericarditis

Incorrect Options:

Large a wave (Option B) – Seen when the right atrium contracts against high resistance, e.g., tricuspid stenosis or pulmonary hypertension.

Canon a wave (Option C) – Occurs when atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve, e.g., complete heart block, VT.

Steep y descent (Option D) – Seen in constrictive pericarditis and severe tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a previous history of rheumatic fever. Examination shows a loud S1 and mid-diastolic murmur is having which of the following valvular heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mitral Stenosis (MS):

Explanation:

  • The patient has a history of rheumatic fever and presents with a loud S1 and mid-diastolic murmur, which are classic findings of mitral stenosis. Rheumatic fever is the most common cause of MS worldwide.
  • Mitral stenosis results from thickening and fusion of the mitral valve leaflets, most often due to rheumatic heart disease. The loud S1 occurs because the stiff valve closes forcefully, and the mid-diastolic murmur is due to turbulent flow across the narrowed mitral orifice during diastole. Other features may include an opening snap and signs of pulmonary congestion.

Mitral stenosis:

  • Cause: Rheumatic fever (most common), congenital, calcific degeneration (elderly).
  • Pathophysiology: Narrowed mitral orifice → ↑ left atrial pressure → pulmonary venous hypertension → right heart strain.
  • Clinical features: Dyspnea, orthopnea, hemoptysis, atrial fibrillation.
  • Auscultation: Loud S1, opening snap after S2, low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur at the apex (best heard with the patient in the left lateral position).
  • Complications: Pulmonary hypertension, right heart failure, thromboembolism.
  • Treatment: Medical (diuretics, rate control for AF) or surgical (percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy, valve replacement).

Incorrect Options:

Tricuspid Stenosis (TS) (Option A) – Mid-diastolic murmur increases with inspiration; usually occurs with MS but isolated TS is rare.

Mitral Regurgitation (MR) (Option B) – Produces a pansystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla, not a mid-diastolic murmur.

Aortic Regurgitation (AR) (Option D) – Produces an early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, not associated with loud S1.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with central chest pain. He has a past medical history of heart disease. ECG is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. - Anterolateral MI:

Explanation:

ECG Findings:

  • ST-segment elevation:

    • Anterior leads: V2–V4

    • Lateral leads: I, aVL, V5, V6

  • Reciprocal ST-segment depression: leads III and aVF (inferior leads)

Interpretation:

  • This combination indicates acute injury involving both the anterior wall (supplied by the LAD) and the lateral wall (supplied by the LCX or diagonal branches of LAD) — hence, anterolateral MI.

  • Reciprocal changes (ST depression in inferior leads) strengthen the diagnosis of acute MI and help differentiate from pericarditis.

MI location vs. ECG leads

MI Location

Leads with ST Elevation

Likely Artery

Anterior

V1–V4

LAD

Lateral

I, aVL, V5, V6

LCX or diagonal branch

Anterolateral

V2–V6, I, aVL

LAD + LCX/diagonal branch

Inferior

II, III, aVF

RCA or LCX

Inferolateral

II, III, aVF, I, aVL, V5, V6

RCA + LCX

Posterior

V7–V9 (or tall R in V1–V2)

RCA or LCX

Incorrect Options:

Inferolateral MI (Option B):

  • Inferolateral MI would have ST elevation in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) plus lateral leads (I, aVL, V5, V6).

  • Here, inferior leads show ST depression, not elevation → rules out this option.

Acute pericarditis (Option C):

  • Pericarditis usually has diffuse ST elevation across almost all leads without reciprocal ST depression (except in aVR/V1) and PR segment depression.

  • This ECG shows localized ST elevation with clear reciprocal changes — typical of MI, not pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis (Option D):

  • Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic condition; ECG may show low voltage QRS or nonspecific changes, not acute ST elevation patterns.

  • It presents with signs like Kussmaul’s sign, pericardial knock, and right heart failure — not acute chest pain + STEMI pattern.

questions.text: During the assessment of drinking water from a village tank, which of the following parameters is not within the acceptable limits for safe drinking water?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Cadmium – 0.03 mg/L

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is Cadmium - 0.03 mg/L because the BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) acceptable limit for cadmium in drinking water is 0.003 mg/L. A value of 0.03 mg/L is ten times higher and is therefore unsafe.

Parameter

Acceptable Limit (mg/L)

Cadmium

0.003

Fluoride

1.0

Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

500

Nitrate

45
  • Cadmium – Toxic heavy metal, harmful to kidneys and bones.
  • Fluoride – 0.8 mg/L is safe and below the limit of 1.0 mg/L.
  • TDS – 300 mg/L is within safe range (limit 500 mg/L).
  • Nitrate – 20 mg/L is below limit of 45 mg/L.

Fluoride – 0.8 mg/L (Option B): Safe; below permissible limit of 1.0 mg/L.

TDS – 300 mg/L (Option C): Safe; below permissible limit of 500 mg/L.

Nitrate – 20 mg/L (Option D): Safe; below permissible limit of 45 mg/L.

questions.text: A patient after MI develops a broad QRS complex tachycardia. His BP is 120/85 mm Hg. ECG is given below. Best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amiodarone IV:

Explanation:

Step 1: Recognising the rhythm

  • Broad QRS (>120 ms)
  • Regular tachycardia
  • Monomorphic appearance
  • Post-MI patient → high risk of ventricular tachycardia (VT)
  • Diagnosis: Sustained monomorphic VT

Step 2: Assessing stability

  • BP = 120/85 mm Hg → patient is hemodynamically stable (no shock, syncope, severe hypotension, or heart failure).
  • In stable VT, first-line pharmacologic management = IV amiodarone (or procainamide in some guidelines).

Class III antiarrhythmic that prolongs repolarisation and suppresses ventricular ectopy. Preferred in structural heart disease post-MI because other agents (like some beta-blockers) may worsen VT in the acute setting.

Stable vs. unstable broad complex tachycardia (VT)

Status

First-line management

Stable VT

IV amiodarone (or procainamide)

Unstable VT

Immediate synchronized DC cardioversion

Pulseless VT / VF

Immediate defibrillation + CPR

Incorrect Options:

Labetalol IV (Option B):

  • Labetalol is an alpha- and beta-blocker used for hypertension, not for acute VT management.
  • Giving it here will not terminate VT and can worsen instability.

Metoprolol IV (Option C):

  • While beta-blockers are used post-MI for arrhythmia prevention, they are not the first choice for terminating sustained VT in the acute phase.
  • Risk of worsening hypotension or bradyarrhythmia once VT resolves.

Nitroglycerin IV (Option D)

  • Used for angina or heart failure due to ischemia.
  • Has no role in terminating VT.
  • May cause hypotension in this context.

questions.text: A study was conducted among nursing staff to analyze the time spent on different aspects of patient care, such as bed preparation, monitoring vital signs, attending the doctor’s rounds, blood sampling, and drug administration. Which of the following management techniques is most appropriate for this type of analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Work Sampling

Explanation:

  • The study in the question focuses on estimating how much time nursing staff spend on various activities across the day, but not by continuously timing each task from start to finish. Work Sampling is the appropriate method here because it involves taking observations at random intervals to determine the proportion of time spent on different activities.

Work Sampling:

  • Definition: A statistical technique for determining the proportion of time spent on various activities by making observations at random intervals.
  • Purpose:
    • Assess workload distribution.
    • Identify major time-consuming activities.
    • Provide data for staffing and scheduling decisions.
  • Applications in Healthcare:
    • Studying nurse-patient interaction time.
    • Determining how much time doctors spend in direct patient care vs. paperwork.
    • Evaluating efficiency in diagnostic labs.

Critical Path Method (Option A): Project management technique for scheduling dependent tasks; not for estimating activity time proportions.

System Analysis (Option B): Studies entire systems and processes; too broad for specific activity-time proportion studies.

Time and Motion Study (Option D): Continuous observation of each step of a task; gives detailed task timings but is more intrusive and detailed than required for this study.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight gain, thinning of hair, and dry skin. Diagnosis is Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Which antibody is seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-TPO antibody:

Explanation:

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas, and it is strongly associated with anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies. These antibodies cause autoimmune destruction of the thyroid gland.

Anti-TPO antibodies target the enzyme thyroid peroxidase, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis (oxidation and iodination of iodine, coupling of iodotyrosines). Their presence confirms autoimmune thyroid disease, especially Hashimoto’s. Other antibodies, like anti-thyroglobulin, may also be present but anti-TPO has the highest diagnostic relevance.

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis:

  • AKA Chronic autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis.
  • Epidemiology: More common in women, especially middle-aged.
  • Pathogenesis: Autoantibodies (anti-TPO, anti-thyroglobulin) → chronic inflammation → fibrosis → hypothyroidism.
  • Clinical features: Weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair thinning, constipation, menstrual irregularities.
  • Lab findings: High TSH, low free T4, positive anti-TPO antibodies.
  • Histopathology:
    • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration
    • Formation of germinal centers
    • Hurthle cells (large oxyphilic epithelial cells with granular cytoplasm) replacing follicular epithelium
    • Atrophic thyroid follicles with dense fibrosis in late stages

  • Treatment: Lifelong levothyroxine replacement.
  • Complications: Increased risk of thyroid lymphoma.

Incorrect Options:

Anti TSH (Option B) – Not seen in Hashimoto’s; would interfere with TSH action, not a diagnostic marker.

Anti TBG (Option C) – Antibodies against thyroxine-binding globulin are rare and not relevant for Hashimoto’s diagnosis.

Long-acting thyroid-stimulating antibody (Option D) – Seen in Graves’ disease, causes hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

questions.text: An RTA patient has received 4 packed RBC within a few hours. Which of the following will be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Hypocalcemia:

Explanation:

  • Stored packed RBCs contain citrate as an anticoagulant. Rapid transfusion leads to citrate binding ionized calcium in the recipient’s blood, causing acute hypocalcemia.
  • Citrate toxicity is more likely when large volumes of blood are transfused rapidly, as in massive transfusion protocols. The liver normally metabolizes citrate, but in shock or hypothermia this clearance is impaired.
  • Clinical signs: Perioral numbness, paresthesia, muscle cramps, tetany, hypotension, and prolonged QT interval on ECG.

Massive Blood Transfusion:

  • Definition: Replacement of blood volume exceeding patient’s total blood volume within 24 hrs (or >10 units of PRBC).
  • Acute complications:
    • Metabolic: Hypocalcemia (citrate toxicity), hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia (from hemolysis), hypothermia, metabolic alkalosis.
    • Coagulopathy: Due to dilution of platelets and clotting factors.
    • Volume overload & ARDS.
  • Prevention: Warm blood before transfusion, monitor electrolytes, give calcium gluconate if needed, replace platelets & FFP in balanced ratios.

Key electrolyte changes in massive transfusion:

Electrolyte

Cause

Change

Calcium

Citrate binding

↓ (Hypocalcemia)

Potassium

Leakage from stored RBCs

↑ (Hyperkalemia)

Magnesium

Citrate binding

↓ (Hypomagnesemia)

Sodium

Usually normal; slight ↑ if using older preservatives

—

Incorrect Options:

Hypernatremia (Option A) – Not a major finding; sodium content in stored blood is minimal.

Hyponatremia (Option B) – Not typically caused by transfusion.

Hyperkalemia (Option D) – Possible in prolonged storage, but acute citrate-induced hypocalcemia is more characteristic in rapid large transfusions.

questions.text: A young female presents with ptosis showing diurnal variation. CT chest shows an anterior mediastinal mass identified as thymus gland cancer. Which receptor is affected in this patient?

choices.text: Voltage-gated calcium channels at the NMJ

questions.solution:
Correct Option B.- Post-synaptic ACh Receptor:

Explanation:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies target post-synaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. Thymic abnormalities (hyperplasia or thymoma) are common in MG.

In MG, antibody-mediated blockade and destruction of post-synaptic ACh receptors reduce the number of available receptors, leading to muscle weakness. Weakness worsens with activity and improves with rest (diurnal variation). The association with thymoma is due to aberrant immune activation in the thymus.

Key features: Ptosis, diplopia, dysphagia, proximal muscle weakness, preserved reflexes, and response to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

Myasthenia Gravis:

  • Epidemiology: More common in young women and older men.
  • Pathophysiology: Autoantibodies against post-synaptic nicotinic ACh receptors at NMJ → impaired depolarization of muscle fibers.
  • Association: Thymic hyperplasia (65%) and thymoma (15%).
  • Diagnosis: Edrophonium (Tensilon) test, anti-AChR antibody assay, repetitive nerve stimulation showing decremental response.
  • Treatment: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (pyridostigmine), immunosuppressants, thymectomy (if thymoma present), plasmapheresis/IVIG for crisis.

NMJ disorders:

Disorder

Site of defect

Antibody target / mechanism

Myasthenia gravis

Post-synaptic membrane

Nicotinic ACh receptor

Lambert–Eaton syndrome

Presynaptic terminal

Voltage-gated calcium channels

Botulism

Presynaptic terminal

Inhibits ACh release (toxin action)

Incorrect Options:

Presynaptic ACh receptor (Option A) – No such pathology in MG; presynaptic issues are rare in autoimmune NMJ disease.

Voltage-gated calcium channels at NMJ (Option C) – Targeted in Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome, not MG.

Acetylcholinesterase (Option D) – This enzyme breaks down ACh in synaptic cleft; it is inhibited pharmacologically in MG treatment, not attacked by antibodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with progressive limb weakness for the past 1 year. On examination, muscle fasciculations and hypertonia are noted, and the sensory system is intact. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis)

Explanation:

ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder involving both upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN), leading to weakness, hypertonia, and fasciculations, while sparing the sensory system. The presence of UMN signs (hypertonia) and LMN signs (fasciculations) together is characteristic.

ALS affects motor neurons in the motor cortex, brainstem, and spinal cord.

  • UMN involvement → spasticity, hyperreflexia
  • LMN involvement → muscle atrophy, fasciculations, weakness.
  • Sensory pathways are usually preserved, helping differentiate from other neuropathies.
  • Onset is insidious and relentlessly progressive, leading to respiratory failure.

ALS:

  • Epidemiology: Usually presents in middle age; more common in men.
  • Pathophysiology: Degeneration of corticospinal tracts (UMN) and anterior horn cells (LMN).
  • Clinical features: Combination of UMN + LMN signs in multiple regions, no sensory loss.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical (exclusion of mimics), EMG shows denervation and reinnervation.
  • Prognosis: Progressive; most patients die within 3–5 years from respiratory failure.
  • Treatment: Riluzole (glutamate inhibitor) modestly prolongs survival; supportive care is key.

LMN and UMN signs in ALS:

Feature

UMN signs

LMN signs

Tone

Spasticity

Hypotonia

Reflexes

Hyperreflexia, Babinski+

Hyporeflexia

Muscle bulk

Normal initially

Atrophy

Fasciculations

Rare

Common

Incorrect Options:

Spinal muscular atrophy (Option B) – Pure LMN disease; no UMN signs like hypertonia.

Multifocal motor neuropathy (Option C) – Pure LMN weakness, usually asymmetric, often with conduction block on nerve studies.

Becker muscular dystrophy (Option D) – Genetic myopathy with proximal weakness, no UMN signs or fasciculations, and onset typically in adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.text: A patient presents with symmetrical leg weakness and areflexia. He had developed diarrhoea 2 weeks ago. He was diagnosed as having GBS. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Demyelination of A, B-fibers:

Explanation:

Guillain–Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy, most often triggered by infections like Campylobacter jejuni. It primarily affects myelinated large-diameter motor and sensory fibers (A and B fibers), leading to weakness and areflexia.

A- and B-fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for motor function and some sensory modalities. In GBS, autoantibodies and immune cells attack the myelin sheath, impairing conduction. This demyelination disrupts both motor signals (causing weakness) and reflex arcs (causing areflexia).

Guillain–Barré Syndrome:

  • Trigger: Often post-infectious (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, Mycoplasma).
  • Pathophysiology: Autoimmune-mediated demyelination of peripheral nerves and nerve roots.
  • Clinical features: Symmetrical ascending weakness, areflexia, minimal sensory loss; may involve cranial nerves (bilateral facial palsy).
  • Complications: Respiratory muscle involvement → respiratory failure; autonomic instability.
  • Diagnosis: CSF shows albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein, normal cell count); NCS shows slowed conduction velocity.
  • Treatment: IVIG or plasmapheresis; avoid steroids.
  • Prognosis: Most recover fully, but some have residual deficits.

Fiber types affected in GBS:

Fiber Type

Myelination

Function

A fibers

Myelinated

Motor + sensory

B fibers

Myelinated

Preganglionic autonomic

C fibers

Unmyelinated

Pain + temperature

Incorrect Options:

Demyelination of B-fibers (Option B) – B-fibers are affected, but not in isolation; A-fibers are also involved.

Demyelination of the spinal cord (Option C) – GBS is a peripheral neuropathy, not a central spinal cord disorder.

Cord inflammation (Option D) – Suggestive of myelitis, which presents with UMN signs and sensory level, not typical in GBS.

questions.text: A patient has developed a cough and weight loss for the last 3 months. Biopsy of lung mass shows expression of chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which paraneoplastic syndrome will most likely occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – SIADH:

Explanation:

Chromogranin and synaptophysin positivity suggests a neuroendocrine tumor, such as small cell carcinoma of the lung. These tumors often produce ectopic ADH, leading to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

In SIADH, excessive ADH secretion causes water retention without corresponding sodium retention, resulting in dilutional hyponatremia and low plasma osmolality. Small cell lung carcinoma is notorious for secreting ectopic hormones, particularly ADH and ACTH. The presence of neuroendocrine markers confirms the tumor’s secretory nature.

Small Cell Carcinoma:

  • Origin: Neuroendocrine Kulchitsky cells in the lung.
  • Markers: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase (NSE).
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes: SIADH (ADH), Cushing syndrome (ACTH), Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome (autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels).
  • Histology: Small cells with scant cytoplasm, nuclear molding, high mitotic count.
  • Prognosis: Aggressive, early metastasis; often unresectable at diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Combination chemotherapy ± radiotherapy; surgery rarely indicated.

Salt and pepper chromatin (black arrows)

Paraneoplastic Syndromes in Lung Cancers:

Lung Cancer Type

Paraneoplastic Syndromes

Small cell carcinoma

SIADH, Cushing syndrome, Lambert–Eaton

Squamous cell carcinoma

Hypercalcemia (PTHrP)

Adenocarcinoma

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

Carcinoid tumor

Carcinoid syndrome

Paraneoplastic syndromes seen in other cancers:

Cancer Type

Paraneoplastic Syndrome

Mechanism / Mediator

Renal cell carcinoma

Polycythemia

Erythropoietin production

Hepatocellular carcinoma

Polycythemia

Erythropoietin production

Ovarian teratoma

Anti–NMDA receptor encephalitis

Autoantibodies to NMDA receptors

Thymoma

Myasthenia gravis

Autoantibodies to postsynaptic AChRs

Breast cancer

Dermatomyositis / Polymyositis

Immune-mediated

Gastric carcinoma

Acanthosis nigricans

Growth factors stimulating melanocytes

Pancreatic carcinoma

Trousseau syndrome (migratory thrombophlebitis)

Hypercoagulability (mucin)

Lymphomas

Hypercalcemia

1,25-(OH)₂ vitamin D production

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Diarrhea, flushing

Calcitonin, VIP

Incorrect Options:

Hypercalcemia (Option A) – Classically associated with squamous cell carcinoma via PTHrP secretion.

Cushing syndrome (Option B) – Possible in small cell carcinoma (ectopic ACTH), but SIADH is more common in this setting.

Gynaecomastia (Option C) – Seen in some germ cell tumors or liver disease, not typical for small cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with palpitations, headache, and sweating. His BP is 180/100 mmHg. 24-hour urinary metanephrine values are elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Pheochromocytoma:

Explanation:

  • Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla. Classic symptoms are episodic headache, sweating, and palpitations with hypertension. Elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines confirm catecholamine excess.
  • Pheochromocytomas arise from chromaffin cells derived from neural crest tissue. Excess secretion of epinephrine and norepinephrine causes paroxysmal hypertension and sympathetic overactivity. Metanephrines are catecholamine metabolites, and their measurement in a 24-hour urine sample or plasma is the most sensitive test for diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • Origin: Chromaffin cells (adrenal medulla).
  • Rule of 10s: ~10% bilateral, 10% malignant, 10% extra-adrenal (paraganglioma), 10% in children.
  • Associations: MEN 2A, MEN 2B, von Hippel–Lindau disease, NF1.
  • Treatment: α-blockade (phenoxybenzamine) before β-blockade, then surgical resection.
  • Histology: Zellballen pattern (nests of cells with rich vascular stroma).

 

Incorrect Options:

Carcinoid tumor (Option A): Presents with flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm; diagnosis by urinary 5-HIAA, not metanephrines.

Carcinoid crisis (Option C): Severe complication of carcinoid tumor with profound hypotension and bronchospasm; unrelated to catecholamines.

Neuroblastoma (Option D): Pediatric tumor of adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain; elevated HVA/VMA (dopamine metabolites), not metanephrines in adults.

questions.text: A patient with osteoarthritis, for the last 3 months, has been taking ibuprofen and has developed occult GI bleeding. Which is correct about the cause?

choices.text: PGE-2 and prostacyclin production were reduced
PGE-1 and prostacyclin production were reduced
Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PGE-2 and prostacyclin production were reduced:

Explanation:

  • NSAIDs like ibuprofen inhibit COX enzymes, reducing prostaglandin (PGE₂) and prostacyclin synthesis. These mediators normally maintain gastric mucosal protection by increasing mucus and bicarbonate secretion and promoting mucosal blood flow.
  • Loss of PGE₂ and prostacyclin leads to impaired gastric mucosal defense, making the mucosa susceptible to acid-induced injury and bleeding. This is the primary mechanism for NSAID-induced gastritis and peptic ulcers. COX-1 inhibition is particularly responsible for GI side effects, as it is involved in constitutive prostaglandin synthesis for mucosal protection.

NSAID-induced GI injury:

  • Mechanism: COX-1 inhibition → ↓ PGE₂, ↓ prostacyclin → ↓ mucus, ↓ bicarbonate, ↓ blood flow.
  • Risk factors: High-dose/long-term NSAID use, elderly, alcohol, corticosteroids, H. pylori infection.
  • Prevention: Co-prescription of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or misoprostol (PGE₁ analog).
  • Histology: Superficial mucosal erosions with inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Complications: Peptic ulcers, GI bleeding, perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Increased acid production (Option B): NSAIDs do not significantly increase gastric acid secretion; the main issue is reduced mucosal defense.

PGE-1 and prostacyclin production reduced (Option C): The main gastric protective prostaglandin is PGE₂, not PGE₁.

Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2 (Option D): COX-2 inhibition is more linked to anti-inflammatory effects and cardiovascular risk, not primary GI mucosal damage (which is COX-1–mediated).

questions.text: What is the name of the technical platform developed under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) to deliver mental healthcare services through a multi-tiered system via telephone, digital platforms, and online portals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Tele-MANAS

Explanation:

  • The technical platform under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) designed specifically for delivering mental healthcare services through telephone, digital platforms, and online portals in a multi-tiered system is Tele-MANAS (Mental Health Assistance and Networking Across States).

Tele-MANAS:

  • Launched by: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India.
  • Objective:
    • Provide accessible, affordable, and quality mental health services across India.
    • Reduce stigma and bridge the treatment gap for mental illnesses.
  • Structure:
    • Tier 1: State Tele-MANAS cells with trained counsellors and mental health professionals answering calls via a toll-free helpline.
    • Tier 2: District-level mental health facilities for in-person follow-up and advanced care.
  • Key Features:
    • Toll-free 24×7 helpline.
    • Multi-language support.
    • Integration with digital platforms and online portals for follow-up care.

NIKSHAY (Option A): Web-enabled application for TB surveillance, monitoring, and patient management under the National TB Elimination Programme.

Quinidine (Option C): An antiarrhythmic and antimalarial drug; unrelated to healthcare IT platforms.

e-Sanjeevani (Option D): National telemedicine service providing online OPD and doctor consultations; not specific to mental health.

questions.text: During a field visit to monitor training given to an ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) on safe immunization practices, you observe that she has used a syringe with a needle, a vaccine vial, and a cotton swab. After completing the immunization, which of the following statements about biomedical waste disposal is correct?

choices.text: The syringe with the needle should be disposed of in a black translucent container
The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag
A used cotton swab should be discarded in a red bag
The needle should be bent and thrown in a red bag

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag

Explanation:

  • Used or expired vaccine vials are considered glass waste and are disposed of in puncture-proof blue containers or blue bags for recycling or proper treatment.
  • Syringes with needles go into white translucent puncture-proof containers without removing the needle, cotton swabs with blood/body fluids go in yellow bags, and needles should never be bent or broken before disposal, as it increases the risk of needle-stick injury.

Item

Waste Category

Disposal Container/Bag

Notes

Syringe with needle

Sharps

White translucent container (puncture-proof)

Needle not removed, container disinfected before disposal

Used vaccine vial (glass)

Glass waste

Blue puncture-proof box/bag

After ensuring vial is empty/expired

Cotton swab (contaminated)

Infectious waste

Yellow bag

If with blood/body fluids

Plastic syringe without needle

Contaminated recyclable

Red bag

For autoclaving/microwaving before recycling

Biomedical Waste Management Summary

  • Fetus, organ, tissue, soiled cotton, gauze, dressings, bandages, casts, plasters, IUD, expired/discarded medicines, cytotoxic waste, body secretions e.g. sputum, pus, feces, X-ray developer fluids, disinfectants, linens, beddings, mattress, gowns, culture plates, blood bags, blood transfusion sets, live vaccine vial, blood products, masks, shoe cover, head cover: Yellow bag for incineration, plasma pyrolysis, and deep burial.
  • Recyclable plastics, tubes, vacutainers without blood, syringes without needles, urobags, catheters, Ryle's tubes, IV drip sets, face shields, goggles: Red bag.
  • Sharps and other metals: White bag.
  • Orthopaedic implants, glassware, artificial pacemaker: Blue bag.

The syringe with the needle should be disposed of in a black translucent container (Option A): Incorrect; sharps go into white translucent puncture-proof containers, not black. Black is for discarded medicines, cytotoxic drugs, or general waste in older systems, but not for sharps under current BMWM rules.

A used cotton swab should be discarded in a red bag (Option C): Incorrect; contaminated cotton swabs go in yellow bags, not red. Red is for contaminated recyclable plastic items.

The needle should be bent and thrown in a red bag (Option D): Incorrect and unsafe; bending needles increases needle-stick risk and sharps never go into red bags.

questions.text: Who is primarily responsible for registering eligible couples for family planning and maintaining their records under the national health system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Multipurpose Worker (Female)

Explanation:

  • Under India’s national health system, the Multipurpose Worker (Female), often synonymous with the Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM), is responsible for registering eligible couples for family planning and maintaining their records.
  • This includes updating the Eligible Couple Register, tracking contraceptive use, and ensuring follow-up services. ASHAs and Anganwadi Workers assist in community mobilization and education but do not maintain the official eligible couple records.

Multipurpose Worker (Female) / ANM in Family Planning:

  • Role in Family Planning:
    • Maintain Eligible Couple Register (ECR) at the sub-centre level.
    • Identify eligible couples (married women aged 15–49 years).
    • Record contraceptive choices and follow-up dates.
    • Distribute contraceptives (condoms, OCPs) and counsel couples.
    • Refer for IUCD, sterilization, or other services as required.
  • Coordination: Works with ASHAs, Anganwadi Workers, and Medical Officers for outreach.

ASHA (Option A): Assists in identifying eligible couples, motivating them for family planning, and distributing contraceptives, but does not maintain the official ECR.

Village Health Guide (Option C): Works in basic health education and minor treatment at the village level; not involved in formal family planning registration.

Anganwadi Worker (Option D): Focuses on nutrition, child care, and preschool education under ICDS; not responsible for maintaining eligible couple records.

questions.text: A HIV-positive patient presents with chronic diarrhoea for 4 weeks. Stool microscopy shows oval/ elliptical cysts measuring 16 X 20 µm. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Cystoisospora:

Explanation:

  • Cystoisospora (formerly Isospora belli) causes chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV. Its oocysts are oval/elliptical, acid-fast, and measure around 20–30 µm (commonly ~16 × 20 µm).
  • Cystoisospora belli infection leads to malabsorptive diarrhea, often chronic in HIV patients. Diagnosis is made via stool microscopy or modified acid-fast staining, showing large oval oocysts. The organism is transmitted via ingestion of sporulated oocysts in contaminated food or water. Treatment typically involves trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

Opportunistic Protozoal GI infections in HIV:

Feature

Cryptosporidium

Cyclospora

Cystoisospora

Size

4-6 μ

8-12 μ

24-36 μ

Shape

Round

Round

Oval

Acid fast (Coccidian cold ZN

stain/Kinyoung)

+

Variable +/-

+

Autofluorescence

-

+

+

Treatment

Nitazoxanide

Cotrimoxazole

Cotrimoxazole

Incorrect Options:

Cryptosporidium (Option A): Much smaller oocysts (4–6 µm); typically causes acute watery diarrhea.

Cryptococcus (Option B): A fungus, not a protozoan; causes meningitis, not diarrhea.

Cyclospora (Option C): Smaller oocysts (8–10 µm) and more spherical.

questions.text: A known case of hyperthyroidism, who is not on medication, is scheduled for total thyroidectomy. The PAC check was not done properly. What is the leading complication that can occur during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Arrhythmia

Explanation:

  • In uncontrolled hyperthyroidism, catecholamine sensitivity is increased, predisposing the patient to severe intraoperative arrhythmias, especially during surgical manipulation of the thyroid gland.
  • A patient with untreated hyperthyroidism undergoing thyroidectomy is at high risk of thyroid storm, precipitated by surgical stress. This can manifest with tachyarrhythmias, hyperthermia, and hypertension. Arrhythmia (especially atrial fibrillation or supraventricular tachycardia) is the most immediate and dangerous intraoperative complication.
  • Proper preoperative control with antithyroid drugs, β-blockers, and adequate preparation is essential.

Incorrect Options:

Hyperthermia (Option A): Can occur in thyroid storm but is not the leading intraoperative danger; arrhythmia is more acutely life-threatening.

Hypothermia (Option B): Not typically associated with hyperthyroidism; more a concern in prolonged surgeries in cold OR environments.

Hypothyroidism (Option D): Develops postoperatively, not during surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with deep-seated retro-orbital pain of cluster headache. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Oxygen:

Explanation:

  • High-flow 100% oxygen is the most effective acute abortive therapy for cluster headaches, rapidly relieving pain within 15–20 minutes in most cases. It is safe, well-tolerated, and works faster than most medications.
  • Cluster headaches are severe unilateral headaches with autonomic features. Acute attacks require rapid-acting treatment — high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreather mask or subcutaneous sumatriptan are first-line.
  • Oxygen relieves pain by causing vasoconstriction and possibly modulating trigeminal-autonomic reflexes. Prophylaxis (e.g., verapamil, lithium) is started later to prevent recurrences, but during an acute attack, oxygen is the gold standard.

Cluster Headache:

Feature

Cluster Headache

Pain

Severe, unilateral, retro-orbital/temporal

Duration

15–180 minutes per attack

Frequency

Up to 8/day during cluster periods

Autonomic signs

Lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, ptosis, miosis

Triggers

Alcohol, histamine, nitroglycerin during cluster period

Acute treatment

100% O₂ (12–15 L/min), subcutaneous sumatriptan

Prophylaxis

Verapamil (drug of choice), lithium, topiramate

Incorrect Options:

Verapamil (Option A): Used for prophylaxis, not acute attack.

Lithium (Option C): Alternative prophylactic agent in refractory cases.

Topiramate (Option D): Used in prophylaxis for migraine and sometimes cluster headache, not acute management.

questions.text: Patient presents with hypertension and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. CT scan shows a mass over the kidney with elevated ARR. What is the next best step for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Adrenalectomy:

Explanation:

  • This patient likely has primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome) due to an adrenal adenoma. In unilateral disease confirmed by imaging and biochemistry (elevated Aldosterone–Renin Ratio), surgical adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice.
  • Hypertension + hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis + high ARR + adrenal mass suggests unilateral aldosterone-producing adenoma. After confirming lateralization (often with adrenal venous sampling in some protocols), the definitive treatment is laparoscopic adrenalectomy. Medical management with mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (spironolactone/eplerenone) is reserved for bilateral adrenal hyperplasia or non-surgical candidates.

Primary Hyperaldosteronism:

Feature

Primary Hyperaldosteronism

Common causes

Adrenal adenoma (Conn’s), bilateral adrenal hyperplasia

Key features

Hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis

Screening

Elevated ARR (Aldosterone–Renin Ratio)

Confirmatory tests

Saline suppression test, fludrocortisone suppression test

Treatment – unilateral

Surgical adrenalectomy

Treatment – bilateral

Spironolactone/eplerenone

Incorrect Options:

Spironolactone (Option A): First-line for bilateral hyperplasia or non-surgical patients, not preferred for unilateral adenoma in a surgical candidate.

ACTH stimulation test (Option C): Used for adrenal insufficiency diagnosis, not hyperaldosteronism.

Dexamethasone suppression test (Option D): Used for diagnosing Cushing’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male has had chronic hypercalcemia for the last 1.5 years, but PTH levels are normal. Which of the following is most likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sarcoidosis

Explanation:

  • From the given history, the patient has chronic hypercalcemia but PTH is normal. This means the hypercalcemia is PTH-independent. Sarcoidosis, due to extra-renal production of calcitriol by activated macrophages, presents with hypercalcemia.

Sarcoidosis:

  • Multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, characterized by non-caseating granulomas. In sarcoidosis, activated macrophages inside the granulomas express 1-α-hydroxylase, converting 25-hydroxyvitamin D into 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This leads to increased intestinal calcium absorption and persistent hypercalcemia.
  • Because the calcium level is high, the parathyroid gland decreases PTH secretion, explaining the normal or low PTH levels in such cases.

Feature

Details

Pathology

Non-caseating granulomas in multiple organs

Common Sites

Lungs, lymph nodes, skin, eyes

Lab Findings

↑ Serum ACE, ↑ calcium, normal/low PTH

CXR

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

Diagnosis

Clinical + radiological + biopsy confirmation

Treatment

Glucocorticoids for symptomatic disease

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Malignancy (Option A) – Can cause hypercalcemia via PTHrP or bone metastasis, but presentation is usually acute and associated with systemic symptoms like weight loss; chronic stable picture is less likely.

Parathyroid hyperplasia (Option C) – Would cause elevated PTH, not normal PTH.

Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) (Option D) – Causes hypocalcemia initially due to phosphate retention and decreased calcitriol synthesis; later may cause secondary/tertiary hyperparathyroidism with raised PTH, not normal.

questions.text: On examination, a person has distended neck veins, absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, and a shift of the trachea. What is the management?

choices.text: Bedside CXR in casualty followed by chest tube insertion

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Wide bore needle in 2nd ICS:

Explanation:

  • This is tension pneumothorax – caused by air trapping in the pleural space under pressure.
  • Key signs:
    • Respiratory distress
    • Hyperresonance (air in pleural space)
    • Absent breath sounds (no lung expansion)
    • Distended neck veins (↑ intrathoracic pressure → ↓ venous return)
    • Tracheal shift away from the affected side (mass effect)
  • In tension pneumothorax, waiting for imaging can be fatal.
  • Immediate needle decompression is done in the 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line using a wide-bore cannula, followed by chest tube insertion.

Tension Pneumothorax:

  • Pathophysiology: Air enters the pleural space during inspiration but cannot exit (one-way valve mechanism). This increases intrapleural pressure → lung collapse → mediastinal shift → compression of heart and opposite lung → obstructive shock.
  • Causes: trauma, mechanical ventilation, rib fractures, ruptured bleb.
  • Emergency Management:
    • Needle decompression (life-saving) – 2nd ICS MCL or 4th/5th ICS anterior axillary line.
    • Chest tube thoracostomy in the 4th/5th ICS mid-axillary line after decompression.

Incorrect Options:

Bedside CXR in casualty followed by chest tube insertion (Option A) – Wrong because waiting for imaging delays life-saving decompression.

Pericardiocentesis (Option C) – For cardiac tamponade, not pneumothorax.

Pleurodesis with doxycycline (Option D) – For recurrent pneumothorax, not for acute life-threatening tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A female presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Serum prolactin is elevated. MRI shows pituitary adenoma. Best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bromocriptine

Explanation:

The patient has hyperprolactinemia due to a pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma). Hyperprolactinemia → suppresses GnRH → ↓ LH/FSH → menstrual irregularities and infertility. First-line treatment for prolactinomas is dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine or Cabergoline) as they inhibit prolactin secretion and can shrink the tumor. Bromocriptine is safe in women desiring pregnancy.

Surgery (trans-sphenoidal resection) is reserved for drug-resistant or compressive symptoms (e.g., visual loss).

Prolactinoma:

  • Causes:
    • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
    • Drugs: antipsychotics, metoclopramide
    • Hypothyroidism (↑ TRH → ↑ prolactin)
  • Symptoms:
    • Women: amenorrhea, galactorrhea, infertility
    • Men: decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, gynecomastia
    • Mass effect: headaches, bitemporal hemianopia if the optic chiasm is compressed
  • Diagnosis: serum prolactin, MRI brain with pituitary protocol
  • Treatment: dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine, Cabergoline) → surgery if not responsive

Incorrect Options:

Letrozole (Option B) – Aromatase inhibitor for estrogen-dependent breast cancer and infertility, not first-line for prolactinoma.

Tamoxifen (Option C) – Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used in breast cancer, unrelated to prolactinomas.

Goserelin (Option D) – GnRH agonist used in prostate/breast cancer and endometriosis, not for prolactinoma.

questions.text: A child with progressive pallor and bone has an elevated HbS based on the HPLC report. Which is the best treatment to manage hemolysis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Voxelotor:

Explanation:

  • HPLC (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography) showing elevated HbS indicates Sickle Cell Disease (SCD). SCD is due to a mutation in β-globin gene → HbS polymerizes under low oxygen → sickling → chronic hemolysis + vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Voxelotor is an HbS polymerization inhibitor that increases hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, stabilizing the oxygenated form and reducing RBC sickling. This directly reduces hemolysis and improves anemia, making it the best treatment here for hemolysis control.

Sickle Cell Disease (SCD):

  • Pathophysiology: Point mutation (Glu → Val) in β-chain of Hb → polymerization in deoxygenated state → distorted RBCs → hemolysis + microvascular occlusion.
  • Clinical features:
    • Hemolytic anemia (pallor, jaundice, gallstones)
    • Pain crises (bone pain, chest pain, abdomen)
    • Dactylitis in children
    • Splenic infarction → functional asplenia → infection risk
  • Diagnosis: HPLC / electrophoresis (↑ HbS, ± HbF, ↓ HbA)
  • Management:
    • Hydroxyurea (↑ HbF, reduces crises)
    • Voxelotor (↓ hemolysis, ↑ Hb)
    • L-glutamine (↓ oxidative stress)
    • Crizanlizumab (P-selectin inhibitor, ↓ vaso-occlusion)
    • Supportive: vaccination, folate, transfusion if needed

Incorrect Options:

Hydroxyurea (Option A) – Increases HbF, reduces frequency of pain crises and acute chest syndrome, but has less direct effect on hemolysis than voxelotor.

Azacytidine (Option B) – DNA methyltransferase inhibitor used in myelodysplastic syndromes/AML, not for SCD.

Bortezomib (Option D) – Proteasome inhibitor used in multiple myeloma, unrelated to SCD.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who exhibits miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Horner syndrome:

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light is suggestive of Horner syndrome. Ptosis is a result of the weakness of Müller muscle and miosis due to the unopposed action of the sphincter pupillae with resultant anisocoria.
  • Pancoast tumor can compress the sympathetic nerves, leading to the classic triad of symptoms seen in Horner syndrome: ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and ipsilateral facial anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

Acquired Neurogenic Ptosis: Acquired ptosis with drooping of the upper eyelid caused by a disruption in the nerve supply to the muscles responsible for elevating the eyelid.

Causes:

  • Third Cranial (Oculomotor) Nerve Palsy: The third nerve can be damaged by trauma, ischemia, infection, tumor, or compression, causing ptosis and diplopia.Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis as it supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.

The ptotic eyelid can be elevated with a frontalis sling or levator aponeurosis advancement.

  • Horner's Syndrome: Involves a lesion in the sympathetic pathway, affecting the Müller’s muscle, leading to mild ptosis accompanied by miosis (pupil constriction) and anhidrosis (loss of sweating).
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine
  • Multiple Sclerosis

Diagnosis:

  • Topical apraclonidine test is now considered the test of choice. Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that also acts as a very weak alpha 1-adrenergic agonist; when topically applied in Horner’s syndrome, it causes dilation of the affected pupil and possibly lid elevation, without change to the normal pupil.

Incorrect Options:

Adie’s tonic people (Option A) It is a unilateral condition and is characterized by anisocoria (different size of pupil) and direct light reflex is sluggish or absent.

Marcus gunn pupil (Option C) Aka relative afferent pupillary defect is characterized by paradoxical dilatation of both the pupil when light is flashed on the diseased eye.

Argyll Robertson pupil (Option D) It is a specific sign of late-stage syphilis. The bilaterally small pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with weakness, back pain and repeated infections. Work up shows M spike on serum electrophoresis. Prognosis is determined by which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Albumin and β₂-microglobulin

Explanation:
The International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma — a widely accepted prognostic model — uses two lab values: serum β₂-microglobulin and serum albumin.

  • β₂-Microglobulin is a marker of tumor burden and renal function; elevated levels indicate more advanced disease and poorer prognosis.
  • Albumin reflects the patient’s general health and disease activity; lower levels are associated with more aggressive disease and worse outcomes.

ISS Staging

Stage

Criteria

Prognosis

I

β₂-microglobulin < 3.5 mg/L albumin ≥ 3.5 g/dL

Best prognosis

II

Intermediate values (not fitting I or III)

Intermediate prognosis

III

Intermediate values (not fitting I or III)

Poor prognosis

Incorrect Options:

IgG and albumin (Option A): While IgG is commonly the paraprotein in multiple myeloma, it is not part of the ISS prognostic criteria.

IgM and albumin (Option B): Elevated IgM is characteristic of Waldenström macroglobulinemia, which differs from multiple myeloma in pathology and prognosis.

Albumin and LDH (Option C): Elevated LDH may suggest high tumor turnover or aggressive disease but is not part of standard ISS staging (though it may appear in the Revised-ISS combined with cytogenetics).

questions.text: A young male patient has the following serological status: HbsAg positive, IgM anti Hbc negative, IgG Anti-Hbc positive and HBeAg positive. Select the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Lamivudine:

Explanation:

  • The serology indicates chronic active hepatitis B infection:
    • HBsAg positive → Ongoing HBV infection.
    • IgM anti-HBc negative, IgG anti-HBc positive → Chronic (not acute) phase.
    • HBeAg positive → High viral replication and infectivity.
  • Patients with chronic active HBV and high viral load (HBeAg positive) require antiviral therapy to suppress viral replication and reduce liver inflammation, fibrosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma risk.
  • Lamivudine, an oral nucleoside analog, inhibits HBV DNA polymerase and is one of the older but effective drugs in HBV management (though tenofovir and entecavir are now preferred first-line due to less resistance).

Incorrect Options:

Ombitasvir (Option B): NS5A inhibitor used in hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection — not active against HBV.

Ritonavir (Option C): Protease inhibitor booster used in HIV therapy — no role in HBV monoinfection treatment.

Abacavir (Option D): NRTI used in HIV therapy — not effective against HBV.

questions.text: A patient with RTA is passing red color urine due to myoglobinuria. Which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Hyperkalemia:

Explanation:

  • Myoglobinuria typically occurs after rhabdomyolysis, where muscle breakdown releases myoglobin and intracellular potassium into the bloodstream.
  • Myoglobin is nephrotoxic, causing acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
  • Tubular injury in ATN often impairs potassium excretion, resulting in Type 4 RTA physiology, which is characterized by hyperkalemia and mild metabolic acidosis.
  • The potassium rise is further exacerbated by direct release from damaged muscle cells.

Incorrect Options:

Hypernatremia (Option A): Less common in ATN; if anything, sodium tends to be low due to renal losses and fluid shifts.

Hyponatremia (Option C): Can occur in kidney injury but not a hallmark feature of RTA with rhabdomyolysis.

Hypokalemia (Option D): Seen in Type 1 (distal) and Type 2 (proximal) RTA, but not in Type 4 RTA or ATN — here potassium retention predominates.

questions.text: A patient after RTA had a renal shut down. Work-up shows: FeNa: < 1%, Urine osmolality: 300 mOsm/kg, Urinary sodium: 40 mEq/L. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN):

Explanation:

  • This presentation points to intrinsic renal injury, specifically ATN, where damaged renal tubules lose the ability to reabsorb sodium and concentrate urine.
  • Key features in this case:
    • Urinary sodium > 40 mEq/L → tubular sodium wasting
    • Urine osmolality ~300 mOsm/kg → isosthenuria (urine similar to plasma)
    • FeNa < 1% is more typical of pre-renal AKI, but in early ATN or mixed states it can also be low.
    • Here, the high urinary sodium and poor urine concentration outweigh FeNa alone, supporting ATN.

Clinical Phases of ATN

Phase

Description

Prerenal Phase (Pre-ATN)
  • ↓ Renal perfusion (e.g., hypovolemia, CHF)
  • Tubular function intact
  • FeNa <1%, BUN:Cr >20
  • Responds to fluids
  • Reversible if corrected early

Initiation Phase
  • Time of original injury (ischemia/toxins)
  • Mild ↓ GFR, slight ↑ creatinine
  • Urine output may be normal
  • Damage beginning but potentially reversible

Extension Phase

  • Ongoing injury + inflammation (days 1–3)
  • Tubular necrosis, obstruction
  • Key sign: ↑ Creatinine + new oliguria despite fluids
  • FeNa >2%, granular casts may appear

Maintenance Phase
  • Established tubular damage
  • Low GFR, sustained ↑ creatinine/BUN
  • Oliguric or non-oliguric
  • Electrolyte imbalances: hyperkalemia, acidosis

Recovery (Repair) Phase
  • Tubular regeneration
  • Polyuric phase: ↑ urine output
  • Gradual ↓ creatinine
  • Risk: volume depletion, electrolyte loss

 

Incorrect Options:

Pre-renal AKI (Option B):

  • Characterized by low urinary sodium (<20 mEq/L) and high urine osmolality (>500 mOsm/kg).

Post-renal AKI (Option C):

  • Labs are variable; diagnosis usually requires imaging evidence of obstruction.

Renal AKI (Option D):

  • Too broad; ATN is the specific intrinsic renal diagnosis here.

questions.text: A patient is in ICU and there is a failed attempt of subclavian catheterization. Shortly after, BP drops and the pulse rises. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumothorax

Explanation:
 

  • Subclavian vein catheterization carries a significant risk of pleural injury, which can cause pneumothorax.
  • Air entry into the pleural space leads to reduced venous return, causing hypotension and reflex tachycardia.
  • In the ICU setting, this can rapidly progress to tension pneumothorax, which is life-threatening and requires urgent decompression.
  • Typical signs: sudden drop in BP, tachycardia, respiratory distress, unilateral decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on percussion.

Incorrect Options:

Displacement of ET (Option B): Would cause hypoxia and respiratory distress, but is not directly related to subclavian line attempt.

Air embolism (Option C): Can occur during line placement, but presents with sudden cardiovascular collapse and possibly a "mill wheel" murmur; pneumothorax is more common post failed subclavian attempt.

Dislodgement of ET (Option D): Would cause airway compromise but unrelated to catheterization unless ET manipulation occurred.

questions.text: A patient had a road traffic accident (RTA). NCCT head was normal on admission. The patient later died after several days in the ICU due to coma. Brain biopsy revealed multiple punctate hemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diffuse axonal injury (DAI):

Explanation:

  • Diffuse axonal injury is a primary brain injury caused by shearing forces during high-velocity trauma (e.g., RTA).
  • These forces disrupt axons in the white matter, corpus callosum, and brainstem.
  • On initial imaging, NCCT may be normal or show only tiny petechial hemorrhages; the condition is often diagnosed clinically or via MRI.
  • Histopathology (or biopsy) reveals multiple punctate hemorrhages in deep white matter tracts.
  • DAI often leads to immediate or prolonged coma without a lucid interval and carries a high mortality rate.

 

Incorrect Options:

Ischemic injury (Option A): Usually presents with territorial infarcts and hypoxic changes, not punctate hemorrhages in white matter.

Intraventricular bleeding (Option C): Would be evident on CT and localized to ventricular system, not diffuse white matter punctate hemorrhages.

Subdural hemorrhage (Option D): Characterized by crescent-shaped collection on CT, caused by tearing of bridging veins — not microscopic hemorrhages.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and altered sensorium. Peripheral smear shows multiple ring stages. Best treatment is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Artesunate:

Explanation:

  • Fever with altered sensorium in malaria indicates cerebral malaria — a severe form most often due to Plasmodium falciparum.
  • Multiple ring forms on smear strongly suggest falciparum malaria.
  • Artesunate is preferred over quinine for severe malaria as per WHO guidelines, given its better safety profile, faster parasite clearance, and lower mortality.
  • It is administered intravenously in the acute setting.

Incorrect Options:

Primaquine (Option A): Used for radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale to target hypnozoites in the liver, not for acute severe falciparum malaria.

Quinine (Option B): Historically the drug of choice for severe falciparum malaria, but now replaced by IV artesunate due to superior efficacy and safety.

Chloroquine (Option C): Effective for chloroquine-sensitive malaria, but most P. falciparum strains are resistant, making it inappropriate in this case.

questions.text: Which is the best confirmatory method to ensure the central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chest x-ray:

Explanation:

Importance of Chest X-ray in Central Line Placement

  • Initial Assessment:
    • A chest X-ray should be performed immediately after internal jugular and subclavian line placement to confirm correct catheter placement and rule out iatrogenic pneumothorax.
       
  • Post-Procedure Verification:
    • It is crucial to verify catheter placement and ensure no complications, like pneumothorax, following the procedure.
       
  • Ipsilateral Side Approach:
    • If the internal jugular central venous line (CVL) insertion fails, move to the ipsilateral subclavian vein.
    • A chest X-ray or ultrasound should be performed before attempting the opposite side to prevent bilateral pneumothoraces.

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What defect is seen in Bernard Soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Deficiency of GpIb receptors:

Explanation:

  • Bernard–Soulier syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive platelet disorder characterized by a defect in platelet adhesion due to deficiency or dysfunction of the platelet membrane glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) complex, which is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF).
  • This defect prevents platelets from binding to exposed subendothelial vWF during vascular injury, leading to defective primary hemostasis.
  • Clinically, it presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, prolonged bleeding time, and thrombocytopenia with giant platelets on peripheral smear.

Incorrect Options:

Deficiency of GpIIb/IIIa receptor (Option A): Seen in Glanzmann thrombasthenia — causes defective platelet aggregation, not adhesion.

Deficiency of von Willebrand factor (Option C): Seen in von Willebrand disease — results in both defective platelet adhesion and secondary coagulation defect due to reduced factor VIII stability.

Deficiency of ADP receptors (Option D): Seen in rare platelet function disorders like P2Y12 receptor defects — affects aggregation via ADP pathway, not adhesion.

questions.text: A patient presents with SOB and fatigue. CXR was done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • Asbestosis is an interstitial lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers, often in occupations such as shipbuilding, construction, or insulation work.
  • The hallmark radiologic finding is calcified pleural plaques, especially along the parietal pleura and diaphragm (“peripheral pleural calcification”), along with lower lobe interstitial fibrosis.
  • Patients present with progressive dyspnea and restrictive lung disease on PFTs.

Incorrect Options:

TB (Option A): More commonly involves apical regions, with cavitation and infiltrates; pleural calcifications are uncommon.

Silicosis (Option C): Typically shows upper lobe nodules and “eggshell” hilar node calcification.

Byssinosis (Option D): Cotton dust–related disease, usually without pleural calcification.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive shortness of breath for the last 6 months, accompanied by dry cough. Auscultation reveals bilateral basal end-inspiratory crepitations. There is no history of fever, joint pain, or occupational exposure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – IPF:

Explanation:

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive fibrosing interstitial lung disease of unknown cause, typically seen in older adults.
  • The classic presentation includes gradually worsening exertional dyspnoea and nonproductive cough over months.
  • On auscultation, bilateral basal end-inspiratory “Velcro” crackles are characteristic.
  • Absence of fever, joint symptoms, or occupational dust/fume exposure supports an idiopathic diagnosis rather than secondary interstitial lung disease.

Incorrect Options:

Cor-pulmonale (Option A): Refers to right ventricular hypertrophy and failure secondary to chronic lung disease or pulmonary hypertension; it is a consequence, not the primary cause, of the lung findings here.

Sarcoidosis (Option B): Usually presents with systemic features, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and may involve skin or eyes; less likely here due to absence of extrapulmonary signs and chronicity pattern.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option D): Generally linked to a clear history of antigen exposure (birds, mold, farming) and has a more acute/subacute onset; no such history is present in this case.

questions.text: A patient has a long arm span, hypermobile joints and hypermobile lens. What is the defective protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fibrillin-1

Explanation:

  • The presentation describes Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to defective fibrillin-1, an essential component of microfibrils that provide structural integrity to connective tissue and regulate TGF-β signaling.
  • Clinical features include tall stature, disproportionately long limbs (increased arm span-to-height ratio), joint hypermobility, lens subluxation (typically upward), and cardiovascular involvement (aortic root dilatation, aneurysm).

Incorrect Options:

Collagen (Option B): Defects cause disorders such as Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and osteogenesis imperfecta, which may have joint hypermobility but not the full Marfan phenotype with lens dislocation and long arm span.

Elastin (Option C): Deficiency is associated with conditions like supravalvular aortic stenosis and Williams syndrome, but not the Marfan skeletal and ocular features.

Keratin (Option D): Structural protein in epithelial cells; mutations lead to skin and hair disorders, not connective tissue or cardiovascular manifestations.

questions.text: A child presents with kawasaki disease with multiple small coronary artery aneurysms. Treatment is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aspirin for 6 weeks:

Explanation:

  • In Kawasaki disease patients with small coronary artery aneurysms, low-dose aspirin is continued for about 6 to 8 weeks to prevent thrombosis as the aneurysms may regress over time.
  • The 6-week duration covers the period of highest thrombotic risk during vascular remodeling.
  • Early IVIG administration is also critical during the acute phase to reduce aneurysm

Incorrect Options:

Aspirin lifelong (Option A): Reserved for large or giant aneurysms with persistent risk of thrombosis.

Aspirin for 4 weeks (Option B): Typically used when no coronary involvement is present.

Aspirin and clopidogrel for 6 weeks (Option D): Dual antiplatelet therapy is usually reserved for larger aneurysms or specific thrombosis risk cases, not routine small aneurysms.

questions.text: The infant is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of seizures. ECG shows Hypsarrhythmia. Which drug is preferred for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ACTH

Explanation:

  • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG is characteristic of infantile spasms (West syndrome), a severe epileptic encephalopathy in infants.
  • The first-line treatment is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which helps reduce spasms and improve developmental outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Vigabatrin (Option B): Also effective, especially in infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis, but ACTH remains the preferred initial therapy in most cases.

Valproate (Option C): Used for other seizure types, but less effective for infantile spasms.

Carbamazepine (Option D): Not effective and may worsen infantile spasms.

questions.text: A patient presents with contralateral face, arm, and leg weakness. NCCT shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). What is the most likely location of the CNS bleed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Basal ganglia

Explanation:

  • Intracerebral hemorrhages causing contralateral hemiparesis (weakness of face, arm, and leg) most commonly occur in the basal ganglia, especially the putamen.
  • The basal ganglia hemorrhage compresses the internal capsule where corticospinal fibers run, causing dense contralateral motor deficits.

Incorrect Options:

Midbrain (Option B): Lesions here often cause oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral weakness but are less common sites for primary ICH.

Pons (Option C): Hemorrhages can cause "locked-in" syndrome or quadriplegia, often accompanied by cranial nerve signs, but less isolated hemiparesis.

Medulla (Option D): Hemorrhages here are rare; symptoms include contralateral limb weakness with ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits (Wallenberg syndrome) but not classic hemiparesis alone.

questions.text: What is the management of undulant fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Doxycycline plus rifampicin

Explanation:

  • Undulant fever is a classic presentation of brucellosis, a zoonotic infection.
  • The standard treatment involves combination therapy with doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 6 weeks) plus rifampicin (600–900 mg daily for 6 weeks) to prevent relapse and ensure eradication.
  • Monotherapy with doxycycline alone is insufficient due to high relapse rates.

Incorrect Options:

Doxycycline alone (Option A): Higher risk of relapse if used without a companion drug.

Doxycycline with azithromycin (Option C): Not a standard regimen for brucellosis.

Doxycycline plus ceftriaxone (Option D): Ceftriaxone is used in neurobrucellosis but not standard for uncomplicated cases.

questions.text: A patient has cheilosis with koilonychia and anemia. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Plummer-Vinson syndrome:

Explanation:

  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by the triad of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal webs, and glossitis/cheilosis.
  • Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) and cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth) are classic signs of iron deficiency.
  • This syndrome increases the risk of developing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma if untreated.

Incorrect Options:

Esophageal cancer (Option B): May develop as a complication of Plummer-Vinson syndrome but is not a presenting diagnosis with these features.

Achalasia cardia (Option C): Presents with dysphagia and esophageal motility disorder, but without anemia or cheilosis.

Tylosis palmaris (Option D): A genetic disorder causing thickened skin on palms and soles, unrelated to anemia or cheilosis.

questions.text: Which classification is used for Barrett esophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prague classification:

Explanation:

  • The Prague C & M classification is used for Barrett esophagus, where C denotes the circumferential extent of the Barrett mucosa and M denotes the maximal extent from the gastroesophageal junction, as measured endoscopically.
  • It helps in standardizing reporting and guiding surveillance.

Prague Classification

  • Two key measurements:
    • C (Circumferential extent)
    • M (Maximum extent)
  • Circumferential extent
    • Distance (in cm) from the GE junction to the proximal limit of circumferential Barrett's mucosa
  • Maximum extent:
    • Distance from the GE junction to the furthest proximal extension of any Barrett's mucosa (including tongues or islands)
  • Example:
    • If Barrett's mucosa is circumferentially present for 3 cm, and a tongue extends up to 6 cm:
      • Prague classification = C3M6

Incorrect Options:

Savary-Miller classification (Option B): Used for grading reflux esophagitis severity based on endoscopic findings.

Johnson classification (Option C): Used for types of gastroesophageal reflux depending on the location of the lower esophageal sphincter and diaphragm.

Forrest classification (Option D): Used in upper GI bleeding to describe peptic ulcer bleeding stigmata and predict rebleeding risk.

questions.text: A female patient complains of chest pain while waking up in the morning. Pain is more in winter months. Which of the following best describes this patient?

choices.text: Subendocardial ischemia due to increased demand of myocardium
Increased sympathomimetic drive in morning hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ach-induced coronary vasoconstriction

Explanation:

  • This presentation is classic for Prinzmetal’s (variant) angina, which is due to transient vasospasm of coronary arteries often occurring at rest, particularly in the early morning hours and more frequently in cold weather.
  • Acetylcholine and other vasoconstrictors can trigger the spasm.
  • ECG during pain may show transient ST-segment elevation.

Incorrect Options:

Fixed plaque obstruction (Option A): Seen in stable angina due to atherosclerosis; pain is usually exertional, not at rest.

Subendocardial ischemia due to increased demand of myocardium (Option C): Describes the mechanism in stable angina during exercise or stress, not rest-related vasospasm.

Increased sympathomimetic drive in morning hours (Option D): Plays a role in acute coronary syndromes but doesn’t fully explain the cold-weather, early-morning, rest-related pain due to vasospasm.

questions.text: CSF shows abundant PMNs with low sugar and elevated proteins. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute bacterial meningitis:

Explanation:

  • Acute bacterial meningitis (ABM) is characterized by neutrophilic predominance (PMNs) in CSF, low glucose (due to bacterial consumption and impaired transport), and elevated proteins (due to increased permeability of the blood–brain barrier).

CSF Findings in various types of meningitis:

Type

Opening Pressure

Predominant Cell Type

Protein

Glucose

Gross Appearance

Bacterial Meningitis

Elevated

Polymorphonuclear Neutrophils (PMNs)

Elevated

Decreased

Turbid

Fungal/Tubercular Meningitis

Elevated

Lymphocytes

Elevated

Decreased

Straw-colored (TB meningitis)

Viral Meningitis

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Lymphocytes

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Normal

Normal or Turbid

 

Incorrect Options:

Tubercular Meningitis (Option B): Usually shows lymphocytic predominance, very low glucose, and high protein; PMN predominance may occur early but is not typical for established TBM.

Viral encephalitis (Option C): Typically has lymphocytic predominance, normal or mildly reduced sugar, and mild–moderate protein elevation.

Viral meningitis (Option D): Similar to viral encephalitis in CSF findings — lymphocytic predominance and normal glucose.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presented with hematemesis and was found to have splenomegaly, on examination. There was a past history of exchange transfusion in this child for neonatal jaundice. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Portal vein thrombosis

Explanation:

The presentation of hematemesis and splenomegaly, along with the significant history of exchange transfusion in the neonatal period, strongly suggests portal vein thrombosis.

This condition is a common cause of portal hypertension in children and can result from umbilical vein catheterization during exchange transfusion.

Incorrect Options:

Splenic vein thrombosis (Option A) is also a possibility in a case of splenomegaly, but the history of exchange transfusion suggests a more generalized thrombotic event involving the portal vein.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (Option C) is a condition characterized by the obstruction of hepatic veins, leading to liver congestion. It is less likely in this case, as the presentation of hematemesis and splenomegaly is more suggestive of portal vein involvement.

Liver cirrhosis (Option D): Although it can cause portal hypertension, cirrhosis is uncommon in a 5-year-old without a history of chronic liver disease.

questions.text: A skin graft was performed on an immunocompromised patient using tissue from another immunocompromised individual. Weeks later, the patient developed contractures and systemic symptoms. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Rejection due to recipient T8 cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Graft-versus-host disease:

Explanation:

  • Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) occurs when immunocompetent donor T lymphocytes recognize recipient tissues as foreign and mount an immune response.
  • This typically happens in immunocompromised recipients who are unable to reject the donor T cells.
  • In the context of a skin graft (especially from another immunocompromised individual where donor lymphocytes may survive),
  • GVHD can cause systemic symptoms (fever, rash, liver dysfunction, diarrhea) along with local changes like skin contractures.

Incorrect Options:

Graft failure (Option B): Results from the inability of the graft to establish blood supply, leading to necrosis — it occurs early, not weeks later, and does not cause systemic immune symptoms.

Rejection due to recipient T8 cells (Option C): This is host-versus-graft rejection, not GVHD, and requires an immunocompetent recipient — which is not the case here.

Delayed wound healing (Option D): Common in immunocompromised states but does not explain systemic features or the contractures caused by immune-mediated damage.

questions.text: The finding seen in the image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Herbert’s pits:

Explanation:

  • Herbert’s pits are small, shallow depressions seen at the limbal conjunctiva due to healed limbal follicles in trachoma.
  • They are considered pathognomonic of previous trachoma infection.
  • Pathophysiology: Chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection causes limbal follicles → ulceration → healing with depression.
  • WHO grading: Presence of Herbert’s pits indicates prior active trachoma and is seen in the scarring stage (TS).

Incorrect Options:

Horner-Trantas spots (Option A): White, chalky dots at limbus composed of eosinophils in vernal keratoconjunctivitis, not trachoma.

Pannus (Option C): Superficial vascularization of cornea extending from the limbus, seen in active trachoma and other chronic keratitis.

Arlt’s line (Option D): Linear scar on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, seen in late scarring stage of trachoma, not at the limbus.

questions.text: A patient with pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma now presents with loss of visual field. What visual field defect will be seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bitemporal hemianopia:

Explanation:

  • The optic chiasm contains crossing fibers from the nasal retina of both eyes.
  • Pituitary adenoma commonly compresses the central chiasm from below → affects crossing nasal fibers → loss of temporal visual fields in both eyes → Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Clinical scenario: Gradual, progressive peripheral vision loss, more noticeable while driving or walking.
  • Mechanism: Nasal retinal fibers detect temporal fields → damage leads to bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

Optic Chiasma

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

  • Optic Tract
  • Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB Lesion)
  • Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Post. Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

 

Aspect

Inferior Optic Radiations

(Meyer’s Loop)

Superior Optic Radiations

(Baum’s Loop)

Location of Lesion

Temporal lobe

Parietal lobe

Affected Visual Field

Superior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes

Inferior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes.

Visual Defect

Superior homonymous quadrantanopia (Option D ruled out)

Inferior homonymous quadrantanopia

Associated Symptoms
  • Memory loss
  • Hearing loss
  • Auditory hallucinations
  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Optokinetic nystagmus
 


Homonymous anopia (Option B): Complete blindness in corresponding halves of the visual fields of both eyes (e.g., entire right field loss) - occurs with complete optic tract lesion, not chiasmal compression.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of eye strain. The given image shows the focus of light rays in different meridians in the eye. Which refractive error is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Astigmatism:

Explanation:

  • The image of Sturm’s conoid demonstrates that parallel light rays do not converge to a single focal point, but rather form two focal lines at different distances due to unequal refractive power in different meridians of the cornea or lens.
