questions.text: A patient with a known marginal placenta presents for follow-up. On ultrasound, a 4×4 cm placental mass is noted invading into the urinary bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Placenta percreta

Explanation:

  • Placenta percreta is the most severe form of abnormal placental adherence, where chorionic villi penetrate through the myometrium and serosa into surrounding organs — here, bladder invasion on ultrasound confirms percreta.

Spectrum: Accreta (into myometrium), Increta (deep into myometrium), Percreta (through serosa, into adjacent organs).

Placenta accreta spectrum

Description

Placenta accreta

Villi is firmly adherent to the endometrium

Placenta increta

Villi invades the myometrium

Placenta percreta

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

  • Management of placenta accreta spectrum

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta
  • Remove as much placenta as possible.
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding.

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy.
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics.
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy.

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Placenta previa (Option A): Refers to placental implantation over or near the cervical os; does not invade the bladder.

Placenta accreta (Option C): Involves abnormal adherence to myometrium without invasion beyond it; bladder involvement rules this out.

Placenta previa (Option D): Same as option A — this duplication is likely a distractor; still does not explain bladder invasion.

questions.text: A patient develops profuse uterine bleeding after a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). Oxytocin has already been administered but bleeding continues. What is the 1st step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Uterine balloon tamponade

Explanation:

  • After oxytocin failure in atonic postpartum hemorrhage, the next first-line mechanical measure is to tamponade the bleeding surface with a balloon catheter (e.g., Bakri balloon).
  • This is a quick, fertility-preserving step that allows time for stabilization and is less invasive than surgical interventions.
  • Stepwise approach to atonic PPH: uterotonics → mechanical tamponade → surgical vessel ligation → hysterectomy.

Intrauterine balloon tamponade is often considered the first-line for managing persistent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony when initial treatments with uterotonics are ineffective.

It involves placing a balloon within the uterus and inflating it to apply pressure and reduce bleeding. This method is less invasive compared to other surgical options and can effectively control bleeding in many cases.

Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices

Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices are typically used for uterine atony unresponsive to medications and massage, often as a step before more invasive surgery.

Contraindications:

  • Allergy to any device component or packing material.
  • Retained Products: Should not replace evacuation of retained pregnancy tissue.

Intrauterine Balloon Tamponade

(Option A)

Types: Multiple balloon catheters used for intrauterine tamponade.

Sengstaken tube. Examples:

  • Bakri, BT-cath, ebb complete;
  • Foley's catheter (can hold up to 100 ml of fluids)
  • Condoms

Mechanism: Hydrostatic pressure applied inward to outward against uterine wall to reduce blood flow and facilitate clotting.

Vacuum-Induced Tamponade

Mechanism: Applies low-level intrauterine vacuum (70-90 mmHg) to evacuate blood and clot, facilitating uterine contractions.

Intrauterine Packing

Plain Gauze/Laparotomy Sponges: Traditional packing method; Replaced by balloon tamponade due to its effectiveness.

Hemostatic Gauze: Gauze with additional hemostatic mechanisms

Compressed Mini-Sponges: Novel device.

 

Uterine or hypogastric artery embolization (Option B ruled out)

Candidates

Suitable for patients with persistent, slow, excessive bleeding.

Hemodynamically stable and unresponsive to less invasive treatments.

Procedure

Performed by an interventional vascular specialist using diagnostic angiography.

Gelfoam is the preferred embolizing agent (temporary occlusion: 2-6 weeks).

 

Uterine Devascularization

  • Progressive ligation of more proximal arteries to control uterine bleeding.
  • May require a hysterectomy if unsuccessful.

Bilateral Uterine Artery Ligation
  • Ligation of the ascending branch of each uterine artery at the lateral border of the uterus.

Ovarian and Uterine Artery Anastomosis Ligation
  • Ligation of the anastomosis between ovarian and uterine arteries on each side.

Bilateral Internal Iliac Artery Ligation
  • Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery on one or both sides to reduce blood flow to the uterus.

Uterine Compression Sutures

Techniques involving sutures to compress the uterus and control bleeding.

B-Lynch Suture
  • Envelops and compresses the uterus; most common technique.
  • Effective for uterine atony, simple to learn, safe
  • May increase risk of Asherman syndrome.

Hayman Technique
  • Uses two to four vertical compression sutures without hysterotomy.
  • Suitable after vaginal birth.

Pereira Technique
  • Involves transverse and longitudinal sutures around the uterus without entering the uterine cavity.
  • Requires care to avoid damaging blood vessels, ureters, and fallopian tubes; manual compression before tying sutures.

Cho Technique
  • Utilizes multiple squares or rectangles for uterine compression.

Uterine Artery Embolization

Minimally invasive procedure using interventional radiology to block blood flow by injecting embolic material.

Hysterectomy (Option D ruled out)

It is a last resort for PPH, it may be necessary in cases where other measures have failed or when there are compelling reasons to remove the uterus.

 

Internal iliac artery ligation (Option C): Surgical vessel ligation is more invasive, technically demanding, and reserved for refractory cases when tamponade and less invasive measures fail.

Hysterectomy (Option D): Definitive life-saving step for uncontrolled bleeding when fertility preservation is not possible, but it is a last resort after failure of medical and conservative surgical measures.

questions.text: Patient has variable deceleration. What does that indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Umbilical cord compression

Explanation:

  • Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate with variable timing and shape, often “V” or “W” shaped on CTG.
  • They are most commonly caused by transient umbilical cord compression, leading to sudden changes in fetal circulation.

Variable decelerations:

  • Pathophysiology: Cord compression → brief fetal hypoxia → reflex vagal stimulation → transient FHR drop.
  • Variable decelerations differ from early decelerations (head compression) and late decelerations (placental insufficiency).
  • Management: Maternal position change, amnioinfusion if persistent, treat underlying cause.
  • Severity depends on depth, duration, and frequency of decelerations.

Non-Stress Test (NST):

  • It is a non-invasive test used to assess fetal well-being by monitoring the fetal heart rate and its response to fetal movements.
  • It is typically performed in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • The mother is placed in a semi-reclining position, and two belts are placed around her abdomen to measure the fetal heart rate and detect fetal movements.

Indications for NST:

  • Post-term pregnancy.
  • Decreased fetal movements.
  • High-risk pregnancies (e.g., hypertension, diabetes).
  • History of previous pregnancy complications.
  • Suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

Primary parameters evaluated during an NST:

1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR)

2. Beat-to-beat Variability:
  • Normal: 110-160 bpm
  • Bradycardia: less than 110 bpm.
  • Tachycardia: more than 160 bpm.
  • Fluctuations in the heart rate from one beat to the next.
  • Amplitude range of 6-25 bpm (considered normal).

3. Accelerations
  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.

4. Decelerations

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
  • Variable Decelerations: Can indicate umbilical cord compression.
  • Late Decelerations: Concerning as they may indicate uteroplacental insufficiency.

5. Fetal Movements
  • The presence and frequency of fetal movements are monitored, as decreased movements can indicate distress.

Interpretation:
  • Reactive NST: Indicative of normal fetal oxygenation and autonomic function.
  • Non-Reactive NST may require further testing, such as a Biophysical Profile (BPP) or Contraction Stress Test (CST).

Incorrect Options:

Fetal head compression (Option B): Causes early decelerations that mirror contractions in timing, not variable in onset or shape.

Uteroplacental insufficiency (Option C): Leads to late decelerations — gradual fall in FHR after contraction peaks, reflecting chronic fetal hypoxia.

Maternal hypotension (Option D): Can cause prolonged decelerations or baseline bradycardia due to decreased uteroplacental blood flow, not the abrupt, variable pattern seen here.

questions.text: In a study, an investigator compared the mean blood pressure and standard deviation between two independent groups. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical test to assess the significance of the difference between the two means?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Unpaired t-test

Explanation:

  • The question describes two independent groups where the investigator is comparing mean blood pressure values. The correct statistical test for comparing the means of two independent samples is the unpaired (independent samples) t-test.

Unpaired t-test: A parametric test used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine if the difference is statistically significant.

Assumptions:

  • The two groups are independent.
  • The data is continuous and approximately normally distributed.
  • The variances of the two groups are equal (homogeneity of variance).

Advantages: Simple to apply when assumptions are met.

Limitations: Not suitable for non-normal or categorical data; use non-parametric alternatives like Mann–Whitney U test if assumptions fail.

No. of Groups

Relatedness of Samples

Test Used

2

Independent

Unpaired t-test

2

Paired/Matched

Paired t-test

>2

Independent

ANOVA

Paired t-test (Option A): Used for matched pairs or before–after measurements in the same group; not for independent groups.

Chi-square test (Option C): Used for association between categorical variables; not for comparing means of continuous data.

ANOVA (Option D): Used for comparing means among more than two independent groups.

questions.text: In a case of face presentation during labor, which diameter is seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Submentobregmatic

Explanation:

  • In face presentation, the fetal head is fully extended, and the presenting part is the face with the chin (mentum) as the leading point.
  • The submentobregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is engaged when mentum is anterior, allowing vaginal delivery.
  • Face presentation occurs due to factors like multiparity, cephalopelvic disproportion, or neck masses.
  • Prognosis depends on chin position: mentum anterior may deliver vaginally; mentum posterior usually requires cesarean.

Face presentation of the fetus

  • Attitude: flexed limbs with extended neck
  • Lie: Longitudinal
  • Presenting part: Face
  • Risk factors
    • Maternal factors
      • Multiparity
      • Lateral obliquity of the uterus
      • Contracted pelvis
      • Pelvic tumors
    • Fetal factors
      • Ananecepathy
      • Congenital goiter
      • Congenital bronchocele
      • Increased tone of extensor neck muscles
  • The engaging diameter depends on the extension of the neck
    • Fully extended head - Submentobregmatic diameter 9.5 cm
    • Partially extended head - Submentovertical 11.5 cm
  • Delivery of the head is achieved by flexion rather than extension like normal vaginal delivery
  • Brow presentation can also convert to face presentation as it is unstable.

 

Incorrect Options:

Mentobregmatic (Option A): This is seen in brow presentation (13.5 cm), where the head is partially extended — largest diameter, leading to obstructed labor.

Suboccipitobregmatic (Option B): Seen in well-flexed vertex presentation — the smallest diameter (9.5 cm) and most favorable for vaginal delivery.

Occipitofrontal (Option C): Seen in deflexed vertex presentation (11.5 cm), more difficult to deliver vaginally.

questions.text: Secondary prevention is most useful in the early detection and treatment of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Cervical cancer

Explanation:

  • Secondary prevention involves early detection and prompt treatment to halt disease progression. It is most effective for cancers with a long preclinical phase and a reliable screening test. Cervical cancer fits these criteria - it has a well-defined precancerous stage (CIN), and screening via Pap smear or HPV testing can detect lesions early, allowing for effective intervention.
  • Pancreatic, ovarian, and glioblastoma cancers typically lack effective population-based screening methods and have short asymptomatic phases, making secondary prevention less useful.

Screening methods:

  • Pap smear – Cytological detection of abnormal cervical cells.
  • HPV DNA testing – Detects high-risk HPV strains.
  • Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) – Low-cost alternative in low-resource settings.

  • WHO recommendation: Screen women aged 30–49 years at least once, preferably every 3–5 years.
  • Early treatment of CIN significantly reduces invasive cervical cancer incidence.

Levels of Prevention in Cancer:

Level

Goal

Example in Cervical Cancer

Primary

Prevent onset

HPV vaccination

Secondary

Early detection & prompt treatment

Pap smear screening

Tertiary

Reduce complications & recurrence

Radiotherapy, chemotherapy for invasive CA

Pancreatic cancer (Option A): Usually diagnosed late due to lack of early symptoms and reliable screening tests; secondary prevention is limited.

Ovarian cancer (Option B): No cost-effective, sensitive population-level screening; early detection remains challenging.

Glioblastoma (Option C): Highly aggressive, short preclinical phase, and no screening method for asymptomatic individuals.

questions.text: What is the best diagnostic test for evaluating endometrial pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy

Explanation:

  • Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity and targeted sampling of suspicious areas, making it the gold standard for diagnosing focal and diffuse endometrial lesions.
  • It improves diagnostic accuracy, especially for polyps, submucosal fibroids, and localized carcinoma.
  • Direct visualization prevents sampling errors common in blind methods like D&C or Pipelle.
  • Allows simultaneous diagnosis and treatment (e.g., polyp removal).
  • Particularly useful in abnormal uterine bleeding, postmenopausal bleeding, and inconclusive imaging results.

Incorrect Options:

Pipelle endometrial biopsy (Option A): Minimally invasive and good for detecting diffuse pathology (e.g., endometrial carcinoma), but can miss focal lesions.

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) (Option C): Blind procedure with lower sensitivity for focal lesions; now used mainly for incomplete abortion or therapeutic purposes.

Transvaginal sonography (Option D): Excellent screening tool to measure endometrial thickness but cannot confirm histology.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) absolutely contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. HIV infection

Explanation:

  • Among the listed options, the absolute contraindication for IUCD use is active, untreated HIV infection with immunosuppression and high risk of pelvic infections. In such cases, IUCD insertion can increase the chance of ascending infection and sepsis.
  • Controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus are not absolute contraindications- though they may be considered for caution depending on the patient’s overall health and choice of contraceptive method.
  • Conditions where IUCD use poses unacceptable health risks, as per WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) Category 4.

Absolute Contraindications:

  • Current PID or purulent cervicitis.
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding.
  • Known or suspected pregnancy.
  • Cervical or endometrial cancer.
  • Distorted uterine cavity (e.g., large fibroids).
  • Active, untreated HIV infection with high risk of opportunistic infections.

Safer Alternatives in HIV:

  • Condoms (dual protection).
  • Hormonal methods (with drug–drug interaction checks).

Condition

Category

Remarks

Active HIV with AIDS symptoms

4

Absolute contraindication

HIV on ART, clinically stable

2

Benefits outweigh risks

Unexplained vaginal bleeding

4

Insert only after evaluation

Current PID

4

Treat infection before IUCD insertion

Hypertension (Option A) – Not an absolute contraindication; copper IUCDs can be used safely.

Hyperlipidemia (Option B) – No restriction for IUCD use.

Diabetes mellitus (Option C) – Not an absolute contraindication; copper IUCDs are generally safe unless there is severe infection risk or uncontrolled complications.

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Uterine inversion

Explanation:

  • Uterine inversion occurs when the uterine fundus collapses into the uterine cavity and protrudes through the cervix, often after delivery, leading to a mass in the vagina.
  • It is an obstetric emergency causing severe hemorrhage and shock, usually precipitated by excessive cord traction or fundal pressure before placental separation.
  • Presents with sudden postpartum hemorrhage, shock disproportionate to blood loss, and absence of the uterine fundus on abdominal palpation.
  • Management: Immediate manual repositioning (Johnson’s maneuver) ± uterine relaxants; delay can worsen prognosis.

Incorrect Options:

Uterine rupture (Option B): Tear in the uterine wall, typically in a scarred uterus during labor; presents with fetal distress and abdominal pain, not a protruding mass

Cervical polyp (Option C): Benign growth from the cervical canal; appears as a small, fleshy projection, not associated with recent delivery or uterine fundal absence.

Vaginal vault prolapse (Option D): Descent of the vaginal apex post-hysterectomy; occurs gradually, not acutely postpartum.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female presents with Tanner stage II breast development and white, odorless vaginal discharge. This discharge is most likely due to the action of which hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Estrogen

Explanation:

  • In early puberty, rising estrogen levels stimulate the vaginal epithelium to proliferate and produce glycogen.
  • This glycogen supports lactobacilli growth, leading to acidic pH and physiological leukorrhea — a normal, odorless, white discharge before menarche.
  • Tanner stage II = breast budding; estrogen effects become evident on genital mucosa.
  • Discharge is not associated with infection, pain, or foul smell — reassurance is key.

Incorrect Options:

GnRH (Option A): Hypothalamic hormone that triggers pituitary LH/FSH release; indirectly influences puberty but does not directly cause vaginal epithelial changes or leukorrhea.

Inhibin B (Option C): Secreted by ovarian granulosa cells; inhibits FSH; no role in vaginal discharge production.

B-Lynch suture (Option D): Surgical technique for postpartum hemorrhage control; unrelated to puberty or vaginal secretions.

questions.text: A 36-year-old P2L2 patient diagnosed with severe endometriosis shows pelvic adhesions on laparoscopy. She has undergone tubal ligation and adhesiolysis previously. What is the most appropriate management during laparoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Explanation:

  • The patient has recurrent severe endometriosis with pelvic adhesions despite prior surgery. She has completed her family (P2L2, tubal ligation), so fertility preservation is not required.
  • Definitive surgical option: In women with no fertility desire, total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the gold standard for recurrent/severe endometriosis to remove both the uterus and the main source of estrogen (ovaries).
  • Why this works:
    • Removes disease and adhesions.
    • Prevents recurrence by eliminating estrogen production.
    • Addresses pain and progression risk.

Management of Endometriosis:

 

COC-Combined oral contraceptives

CC-Clomiphene citrate

IUI-Intrauterine insemination

 

  • Medical management of endometriosis includes:

Mild pain

Moderate to severe pain
  • NSAIDs & OCPs (First line)
  • Progesterone (Second line)
  • Continuous GnRH agonist (Third line)
  • Continuous GnRH agonist / GnRH antagonist (First line)
  • Laparoscopy, if medical management fails.
  • Laparoscopy: Investigation of choice in endometriosis, used for diagnosing, staging, and therapeutic management of pain
  • Other Drugs useful in endometriosis are:
    • Aromatase inhibitors (Letrozole)
    • Progesterone receptor modulators (Mifepristone, Ulipristal)
    • GnRH Antagonists (Injection: Ganirelix and cetrirelix)
    • Tab Danazol (400 mg/day)

Incorrect Options:

Observation only, no intervention (Option A): Not appropriate as the patient has symptomatic, severe, recurrent disease impacting quality of life

Total laparoscopic hysterectomy (Option B): Hysterectomy alone leaves the ovaries intact, allowing continued estrogen production and high recurrence risk of endometriosis.

Oophorectomy (Option C): Removing only ovaries will reduce estrogen production but leaves uterine disease untreated; also causes premature menopause.

questions.text: Which of the following occupational exposures is most strongly associated with the development of mesothelioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Asbestos exposure

Explanation:

  • Mesothelioma, particularly malignant pleural mesothelioma, is strongly linked to occupational exposure to asbestos fibers. Asbestos can be inhaled during mining, manufacturing, or use in construction materials, and the fibers lodge in the pleura, causing chronic inflammation and carcinogenesis. The latency period is typically very long (20–40 years).

Asbestos: Group of naturally occurring silicate minerals with heat resistance and insulating properties.

  • Types: Chrysotile (serpentine), amosite, crocidolite (amphiboles — more carcinogenic).
  • Health effects:
    • Asbestosis (interstitial lung fibrosis).
    • Lung carcinoma (Most common)
    • Malignant mesothelioma (pleura, peritoneum, pericardium): Most specific.
    • Benign pleural plaques and effusions.
  • Pathogenesis: Inhaled fibers → persistent pleural irritation → chronic inflammation & DNA damage → malignant transformation.

Silicosis

Sandstone industry, granite industry. Pottery industry, ceramic industry, gold, mica and steel industry, glass factory, building and construction work, rock mining

Asbestosis

Cement factory, fireproof industry, construction, airplanes

Anthracosis

Coalmines

Baritosis

Photography, printing, barium diagnostic works

Byssinosis

Textile industry

Bagassosis

Cane sugar factories, paper and cardboard factories-Fibrous residue from bagasse used in paper factories

Farmer's lung

Agricultural industry

Siderosis

Iron mines, Iron, and steel industry
  • Occupations at risk: Shipyard workers, construction, insulation manufacturing, asbestos mining.

Silica dust (Option B): Causes silicosis and increases risk of TB and lung cancer, but not strongly linked to mesothelioma.

Cotton dust (Option C): Associated with byssinosis (“Monday fever”); no direct link to mesothelioma.

Coal dust (Option D): Causes coal workers’ pneumoconiosis (“black lung disease”); no direct link to mesothelioma.

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast lump, associated with skin dimpling and nipple retraction. What is the most likely anatomical structure responsible for the skin dimpling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suspensory (Cooper’s) ligaments

Explanation: Skin dimpling and nipple retraction in breast carcinoma occur due to fibrosis and contraction of the suspensory (Cooper’s) ligaments.

  • These fibrous bands extend from the dermis of the skin to the pectoral fascia through the breast tissue.
  • When a malignant lesion infiltrates these ligaments, it shortens them, pulling the skin inward → dimpling or puckering.
  • Similarly, infiltration of lactiferous ducts can cause nipple retraction.

Incorrect Options:

Lactiferous ducts (Option A): Involved in nipple retraction when invaded, but skin dimpling is due to Cooper’s ligament involvement.

Pectoral fascia (Option C): Involvement causes fixation of the breast to the chest wall, not skin dimpling.

Subcutaneous fat (Option D): Malignant infiltration of fat contributes to mass formation, not the dimpling effect.

questions.text: What is the embryological cause of this anomaly?

choices.text: Failure of fusion of metanephric duct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-fusion of paramesonephric ducts

Explanation: A unicornuate uterus with a rudimentary horn occurs due to failure of one paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct to develop completely and failure of fusion with the contralateral duct.

Unicornuate uterus caused by the failure of one Mullerian duct to develop, results in a single uterine cavity and fallopian tube, leading to poor pregnancy outcomes. It appears smaller and curved to one side (banana shaped), unlike a bicornuate uterus (heart-shaped).

Representation

HSG of Unicornuate uterus

Incorrect Options:

Non-fusion of mesonephric duct (Option A): Involved in urinary tract development (e.g., vas deferens, epididymis), not uterine formation.

Failure of fusion of metanephric duct (Option C): Metanephric duct is not a term used in uterine development; kidney development involves metanephric blastema, not related here.

Complete agenesis of Müllerian structures (Option D): Seen in Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome — uterus absent bilaterally, unlike here where one side is normal.

questions.text: In the image shown, identify the function of the marked structure on the endotracheal tube.

choices.text: Prevention of air leakage and aspiration
Suctioning of lower respiratory tract secretions

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prevention of air leakage and aspiration

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the inflatable cuff of the endotracheal tube. When inflated, it creates a seal between the tube and the tracheal wall.
    • This seal prevents air leakage during positive pressure ventilation, ensuring efficient delivery of tidal volume.
    • It also reduces the risk of aspiration by blocking secretions from the upper airway from entering the lungs.
    • Overinflation can cause tracheal mucosal injury; thus, cuff pressure should be maintained between 20–30 cm H₂O.

Incorrect Options:

Facilitation of vocal cord visualization (Option A): Visualization is achieved during intubation using laryngoscopy, not by the cuff.

Monitoring airway pressure (Option B): This is done via ventilator circuits, not by the cuff.

Suctioning of lower respiratory tract secretions (Option D): Requires a suction catheter, not the cuff.

questions.text: After an initial serum β-hCG test in a patient with suspected pregnancy, when should the repeat β-hCG level ideally be checked to assess viability or progression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 48 hours

Explanation: β-hCG levels are checked ideally after 48 hours.

In a viable intrauterine pregnancy, the serum β-hCG level should rise by at least ~66% over 48 hours in early gestation.

  • This doubling time is a key marker of normal trophoblastic function.
  • Slower rises can indicate ectopic pregnancy or failing pregnancy, while falling levels suggest miscarriage.
  • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.So if the beta-hCG level is ≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.

questions.text: A long-term study found that individuals who had high blood pressure (BP) during childhood continued to have high BP in adulthood, and those with low BP in childhood tended to maintain lower levels later in life. Which of the following epidemiological concepts does this pattern best represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Tracking of blood pressure

Explanation:

  • Tracking of blood pressure refers to the tendency of an individual’s relative position within a distribution (e.g., BP levels) to remain consistent over time. In other words, those with high BP in childhood often remain at the higher end of BP in adulthood, and those with low BP tend to stay lower - even though absolute values may change with age.
  • This concept is important in predicting adult disease risk from childhood measurements and emphasizes early preventive measures.

Rule of halves (Option A): Refers to the observation in hypertension that only half of all hypertensives are diagnosed, half of them are treated, and half of those treated achieve control. It does not describe lifelong consistency in BP levels.

Regression to the mean (Option B): This is a statistical phenomenon where extreme values tend to move closer to the average on subsequent measurements. It does not imply consistent rank ordering over time.

Cohort effect (Option D): Refers to differences in health outcomes between groups born in different time periods due to shared exposures or experiences. It is unrelated to the persistence of BP levels within the same individuals.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a short cervix undergoes a cervical cerclage procedure.  What is the most likely procedure performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Modified Shirodkar

Explanation: The modified Shirodkar cerclage is a variation of the original Shirodkar procedure, performed for cervical insufficiency in pregnant women with a short or incompetent cervix.

  • In the Shirodkar technique, a suture (usually Mersilene tape) is placed at the level of the internal os after dissecting the bladder and rectum off the cervix, allowing a higher placement than the McDonald’s method.
  • The modified version often uses less extensive bladder dissection or different suture materials, making it technically simpler but still allowing high placement for better cervical support.
  • This technique is especially indicated when a high and strong cerclage is desired, such as in women with significant cervical shortening early in pregnancy.

Cerclage placement in cervical insufficiency:

Transvaginal route:

  • More commonly preferred than the transabdominal route due to the ease of the procedure
  • It is an outpatient procedure and local anaesthesia is preferred.
  • McDonald’s cerclage:
    • More commonly used than Shirodkar’s procedure
    • A purse-string suture with a non-absorbable suture is applied at the cervicovaginal junction.
  • Shirodkar’s cerclage:
    • The cervicovaginal junction is cut and continuous, non-absorbable sutures (using Mersilene tape) are applied at the internal os.

  • Wurm’s stitch (or rescue stitch) is used when a woman presents with cervical dilatation and bulging fetal membranes.

Transabdominal route:

  • It is done only when vaginal cerclage fails or severe cervical anatomical defects are present.
  • Performed less commonly than vaginal cerclage.
  • The suture is placed abdominally at the uterine isthmus
  • The cerclage is left until childbearing is completed and therefore cesarean delivery is required

In both transvaginal and transabdominal procedures, after the placement of cerclage, the patient should be started on progesterone up to 36 weeks+6 days of gestation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes for emergency contraception within 8 hours after engaging in sexual intercourse. She expresses a preference for a single pill rather than multiple pills. What would be your recommendation in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

Explanation:

  • Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the most appropriate option for emergency contraception in this case. It is a progestin-only pill and is highly effective when taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse. Since the patient prefers a single-pill regimen, this option is ideal. It does not contain estrogen, avoiding estrogen-related side effects such as nausea or vomiting.

Emergency Contraceptive Methods

Method

Drug(s)

Dosage

Schedule

Time Period for Use

Oral Contraceptive Pills

Levonorgestrel

1.5 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Combination Pills (Yuzpe Regimen)

Levonorgestrel + Ethinyl estradiol

Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg + Ethinyl estradiol 0.1 mg per tablet

2 doses, 12 hours apart

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Levonorgestrel

Levonorgestrel

0.75 mg per tablet (take 2 tablets)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Ulipristal Acetate

Ulipristal acetate

30 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex

Copper IUD (Best)

Copper IUD

N/A (inserted by healthcare provider)

Insertion by a healthcare provider

Within 5 days after unprotected sex

Mifepristone (Less Common)

Mifepristone (in combination with misoprostol)

200 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Incorrect Options:

While levonorgestrel 0.75 mg (Option A) is used in some regimens, it requires two doses (one pill initially and another 12 hours later). Since the patient prefers a single pill, this option is not suitable.

Ethinyl estradiol + levonorgestrel (Option B) combination contains both estrogen (ethinyl estradiol) and progestin (levonorgestrel). While effective, the estrogen component increases the risk of side effects, including nausea and vomiting, which the patient is trying to avoid.

Desogestrel 3 mg (Option D) is a progestin-only contraceptive, but it is not typically used for emergency contraception. Furthermore, it is often combined with estrogen, which would introduce unnecessary side effects.

questions.text: A patient presents with obstructed labor, and on abdominal examination, a groove or band is palpable across the uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bandl’s ring

Explanation: A Bandl’s ring is an abnormal pathological retraction ring that forms between the upper contractile segment and the lower thin, stretched segment of the uterus during obstructed labor.

  • On abdominal examination, it presents as a palpable transverse or oblique groove running across the uterus. It is associated with prolonged obstructed labor and is a sign of impending uterine rupture if not managed promptly.
 

Bandl's Ring

Schroeder's Ring

(Option B)

Definition

An abnormal ring of constriction that forms in the uterus, typically between the lower and upper uterine segments. It causes an extreme form of uterine atony

A pathological ring of constriction that can occur in any stage of labor, resulting from oxytocin overuse, and may lead to uterine rupture

Cause

Prolonged second stage of labor

Oxytocin overuse, or misuse of uterine stimulants

Stage of Labor

Second stage of labor

Any stage of labor

Management

Cesarean section

Discontinuation of oxytocin, relaxation of the uterus (using tocolytics), and possible cesarean section depending on severity

Constriction ring (Option A): Localized spasm of a small portion of the myometrium, usually around the fetus; not felt as a transverse groove across the abdomen.

Contraction ring (Option C): Normal physiological junction between upper and lower uterine segments; not pathologically elevated or palpable in normal labor.

questions.text: The waveform shown in the image represents which of the following physiological parameters?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - End tidal carbon dioxide

The image is of a waveform which represents end-tidal carbon dioxide (EtCO2). This is a capnography waveform, a non-invasive monitoring technique used in anesthesia to measure the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) at the end of each breath.

A typical capnography waveform consists of four distinct phases:

  • Phase I (Inspiration): The baseline represents a zero CO2 level, as the patient is inhaling fresh gas without any CO2.
  • Phase II (Early Expiration): This phase shows a rapid increase in CO2 as the anatomical dead space is exhaled, mixing with alveolar gas.
  • Phase III (Alveolar Plateau): The CO2 concentration reaches a plateau as gas from the alveoli is exhaled. The end of this phase, point E, is the end-tidal CO2 value.
  • Phase IV (Inspiration): A sharp downstroke to the baseline as inspiration begins and fresh gas dilutes the CO2 in the airway.

Incorrect Options:

Arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) (Option A): This is measured by a pulse oximeter and is displayed as a plethysmographic waveform, not a capnogram. The SpO2 waveform is a pulsatile wave that reflects blood flow and oxygenation, not the gas exchange pattern of respiration.

Functional residual capacity (FRC) (Option C): FRC is a lung volume, the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. It is not measured with a waveform but through specific pulmonary function tests.

Tidal volume (VT) (Option D): Tidal volume is the amount of air inhaled or exhaled in a single breath. While the capnogram provides information about the breath cycle, the waveform itself does not directly measure the volume of air. Instead, it measures the concentration of CO2 over time, from which tidal volume can be inferred through other calculations.

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant presents with a scrotal swelling that has been present since birth. Now, the swelling has become suddenly painful, red, and irreducible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strangulated inguinal hernia

Explanation: The infant has a congenital scrotal swelling (likely due to a hernia present since birth) that has become painful, red, and irreducible, suggesting that bowel has entered the hernial sac and is now compromised with vascular obstruction - this is the definition of a strangulated inguinal hernia.

  • This is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent bowel necrosis.

Strangulated Hernia:

  • A strangulated hernia occurs when a portion of tissue or intestine protrudes through a weakened area in the abdominal wall and becomes trapped.
  • The trapped segment loses its blood supply, leading to tissue ischemia (lack of blood flow) and potential tissue death if not promptly treated.

Clinical Features:

  • Irreducibility: The hernia cannot be pushed back.
  • Signs of Intestinal Obstruction: Colicky pain, bilious vomiting, absence of faeces and flatus.
  • History: Sudden onset of pain at the hernia site, followed by generalised abdominal pain.
  • Physical Examination Findings: Tense, extremely tender hernia with reddish or bluish skin discolouration and no cough impulse.
  • Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical examination and physical findings.

Treatment:

  • Initial Resuscitation:
    • Administer intravenous (IV) fluids.
    • Provide IV antibiotics.
    • Perform nasogastric aspiration.
    • Insert Foley's catheter.
  • Surgical intervention is done only after Initial Resuscitation.

Surgical management Algorithm:

Mesh Usage:

  • Synthetic mesh is contraindicated due to the increased risk of infection.
  • If a mesh is necessary, bioprosthetic or absorbable mesh is preferred.

Acute epididymo-orchitis (Option A): Presents with scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema but is rare in this age group and usually associated with urinary tract infection; swelling is not from birth.

Testicular torsion (Option B): Sudden severe scrotal pain and swelling, but not present since birth; does not involve an irreducible groin/scrotal mass.

Incarcerated inguinal hernia (Option D): Irreducible hernia without compromised blood supply; no redness or severe tenderness — if blood supply is compromised, it becomes strangulated.

questions.text: A patient underwent split-thickness skin grafting for a burn injury on the arm. On post-operative day 6, he develops stiffness of the arm during physiotherapy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Passive extension of the joint under direct visualization of the graft
Remove the graft and regraft the area

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Passive extension of the joint under direct visualization of the graft

Explanation: By post-operative day 6, the split-thickness skin graft is in the fibrovascular ingrowth and early maturation phase. If stiffness develops during physiotherapy, the safest approach is to perform passive extension under direct visualization to ensure that the graft is not disrupted.

  • This allows assessment of graft integrity and prevention of shearing forces that could cause partial or total graft loss.

Surgical excision of contracture (Option A): Contracture release is indicated in long-standing, mature scars, not within the first week after grafting.

Continue physiotherapy without intervention (Option C): Risk of damaging the graft if stiffness is due to early adhesion or improper graft placement; should first ensure graft safety.

Remove the graft and regraft the area (Option D): Not necessary unless the graft has failed; stiffness alone at day 6 is not an indication for regrafting.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is being assessed for induction of labor. On vaginal examination: Cervical dilation: 2 cm, Effacement: 20%, Cervical consistency: Soft, Position: Midline, Station: –2. What is the modified Bishop Score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Score 5 – Unfavorable

Explanation: A score ≤5 means the cervix is unfavorable for induction, and cervical ripening is needed before oxytocin induction.

  • Cervical dilation (2 cm) = 1 point
  • Effacement (20%) = 1 point
  • Cervical consistency (Soft) = 2 points
  • Position (Midline) = 1 point
  • Station (–2) = 0 points

questions.text: During the management of shoulder dystocia in childbirth, which of the following is the earliest and first maneuver typically attempted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a- McRoberts maneuver

  • Explanation: The McRoberts maneuver is the first and earliest step in managing shoulder dystocia. It involves hyperflexing the mother’s thighs onto her abdomen, which straightens the lumbosacral angle, rotates the pelvis, and frees the impacted anterior shoulder behind the pubic symphysis.
  • Sequence of events in Shoulder dystocia:
  • Help – call for extra assistance → Evaluate for episiotomy → McRoberts maneuver (first maneuver) → Suprapubic pressure → Rubin maneuver → Woods corkscrew maneuver → Delivery of posterior arm → Roll patient to all fours (Gaskin maneuver) → If unsuccessful, consider cleidotomy, Zavanelli maneuver, or symphysiotomy as last resorts.

Incorrect Options:

Woods corkscrew maneuver (Option B): A rotational maneuver used after McRoberts if initial steps fail; rotates the posterior shoulder anteriorly.

Rubin maneuver (Option C): Also a rotational maneuver, but involves pushing the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder toward the chest; not the first-line step.

Delivery of posterior arm (Option D): Usually attempted if initial maneuvers (McRoberts + suprapubic pressure) fail; reduces the bisacromial diameter.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for esophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endoscopic ligation

Explanation:

  • Endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) is the first-line treatment for acute bleeding esophageal varices and for secondary prophylaxis. It works by mechanically strangulating varices, leading to thrombosis and obliteration, with fewer complications than sclerotherapy.

Management of Esophageal varices:

  • The immediate priority in managing variceal bleeding is stabilizing the patient's condition. This involves the airway, breathing, and circulation.
  • Establishing intravenous access with large-bore cannulae allows for rapid fluid resuscitation, ideally with blood transfusions, to restore circulatory volume and address hypotension.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) (Option B): Used as a salvage therapy when bleeding persists or recurs despite optimal endoscopic and pharmacologic management.

Intravenous labetalol (Option C): Not used; nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol or nadolol are used for prophylaxis, not labetalol.

Oral amoxicillin (Option D): Antibiotics (usually ceftriaxone) are given prophylactically in variceal bleeding, but amoxicillin is not the standard choice and does not control bleeding.

questions.text: OCPs can be given in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HIV

Explanation:

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are generally contraindicated in certain high-risk conditions due to their estrogen component, which can increase the risk of thromboembolic and cardiovascular events.

  • In HIV, OCPs can still be used safely, though drug interactions with some antiretroviral drugs may occur, but HIV itself is not a contraindication.

Complications associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Complication

Details

Minor Complications

Nausea, Vomiting, Headache

Common initial side effects due to hormonal changes; usually resolves over time. Consider dose adjustment if persistent.

Mastalgia

Breast tenderness or pain; typically resolves within a few cycles.

Weight Gain

Minimal long-term weight gain

Menstrual Abnormalities

Includes breakthrough bleeding, hypomenorrhea, menorrhagia, and amenorrhea; often resolves with continued use.

Libido

Changes in sexual desire can occur

Leukorrhea

Increase in vaginal discharge

Major Complications

Depression

Mood changes or depression related to hormonal fluctuations

Hypertension

Elevated blood pressure; requires regular monitoring and possible medication adjustment.

Vascular Complications
  • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): Increases risk three to fivefold, especially in those with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or smoking. (Option A)
 
  • Arterial Thrombosis: Increased risk of stroke and myocardial infarction

Cholestatic Jaundice

Liver dysfunction resulting in jaundice; Resolves after discontinuation of OCPs.

Neoplasia

Association with cervical cancer; regular Pap smears recommended for screening.

Incorrect Options:

HTN (Option A): Moderate to severe uncontrolled hypertension is a contraindication to combined OCPs due to increased cardiovascular risk.

DM (Option B): In diabetics with vascular complications or >20 years duration of disease, OCPs are contraindicated due to the risk of worsening microvascular disease.

Hyperlipidemia (Option D): Uncontrolled hyperlipidemia is a contraindication as estrogen can further raise triglyceride levels and cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: Identify the types of sutures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Simple Interrupted suture

Explanation: The image depicts Simple interrupted suture.
