questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Venous ulcer

Explanation:

  • An ulcer in the gaiter area (medial aspect of the lower leg, above the ankle) is most commonly due to chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are typically shallow, have irregular margins, and are associated with skin changes like hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and edema.

The type of ulcer edges seen in various clinical conditions is listed in the table below:

Type of edges

Clinical conditions

Details

Sloping edge
  • Healing ulcer
  • Varicose ulcer

Inner part: Red (healthy granulation tissue)

Middle part: Blue (epithelial proliferation)

Outer part: White (scar/fibrous tissue)

Undermined edge
  • Tubercular ulcers

Disease process advances in the deeper plane (subcutaneous tissue) whereas (skin) epidermis proliferates inwards

Punched out edge
  • Arterial / Ischemic ulcers
  • Gummatous (syphilitic) ulcer
  • Trophic ulcer

Due to endarteritis

Raised and beaded edge

Rolled out / Pearly white edge
  • Rodent ulcer- Basal cell carcinoma
  • Beads are due to proliferating active cells
  • Pearly white in appearance

Everted edge / Rolled out edge
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Due to the spill of proliferating malignant tissue over the normal skin

 

Arterial ulcer (Option A): Usually found on toes, dorsum of foot, or pressure points; have “punched-out” edges, very painful, and are associated with diminished pulses.

Diabetic ulcer (Option C): Typically over pressure points of the foot (metatarsal heads, heel) due to neuropathy; often painless.

Neuropathic ulcer (Option D): Similar to diabetic ulcers but specifically due to peripheral neuropathy from any cause; usually over pressure-bearing areas.

questions.text: A 46 year male had a tumor in his left lobe of liver, so left sided hemi hepatectomy was planned, which of the following lobes of liver will be resected in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:

Explanation: Liver lobes are defined surgically based on Couinaud's segmental anatomy (functional anatomy), which follows the portal vein and hepatic vein divisions rather than the classical anatomical right/left lobes.

In a left hemihepatectomy, the left functional lobe is removed.

  • This includes segments II, III, and IV:
    • Segment II & III: Left lateral section
    • Segment IV: Left medial section

Segments of the liver

Segment VIII:

  • The superior part of the right anterior sector.
  • Drainage: Drains into the right and middle hepatic veins.

Segment I (Caudate Lobe):

  • Posterior to segment IV, straddles the inferior vena cava.
  • Drainage: Multiple small veins drain directly into the inferior vena cava.
  • Bile Ducts: Related to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts.

Segment II:

  • Posterolateral to the left portal fissure.
  • Drainage: Drains into the left hepatic vein; rarely directly into the inferior vena cava.

 

Segment VII:

  • The superior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right hepatic vein.
  • Drainage: Primarily into the right hepatic vein; occasionally directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment III:

  • Between the umbilical and left portal fissures.
  • Drainage: Primarily into the left hepatic vein; alternative drainage via falciform ligament veins.

Segment VI:

  • Inferior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right portal fissure.
  • Drainage: Usually into the right hepatic vein; may drain directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment V:

  • Inferior segment of the right anterior sector.
  • Drainage: Typically into the right and middle hepatic veins; can drain directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment IV:

  • Between the umbilical fissure and main portal fissure, anterior to segment I.
  • Drainage: Usually into the middle hepatic vein; can also drain into the left hepatic vein.

1, 2 & 3 (Option B): Segment I is the caudate lobe, which is functionally separate and not routinely removed in a left hemihepatectomy.

5, 6, 7 & 8 (Option C): These are part of the right functional lobe.

2, 3, 4 & 5 (Option D): Segment 5 belongs to the right lobe.

questions.text: A woman sustains a perineal tear during delivery. Examination reveals that less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is involved. Based on the classification system, what is the most appropriate description of this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3a

Explanation:

Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn (Option C)
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn (Option B)
  • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

Fourth degree (Option D)

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

 

Risk factors of perineal tear:

  • Big baby(weight ≥ 3 kg).
  • Nulliparity.
  • Outlet contraction with narrow pubic arch.
  • Shoulder dystocia.
  • Forceps delivery.
  • Scar in the perineum (perineorrhaphy, episiotomy).
  • Face to pubis delivery.
  • Midline episiotomy.
  • Precipitate labour.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has developed breast and pubic hair. The mother wants to know which sign of puberty will typically occur next?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Peak height

Explanation:

Pubertal development in girls generally follows Tanner’s sequence:

  1. Thelarche – breast development (usually the first sign, ~8–11 years)
  2. Pubarche – pubic hair development
  3. Peak height velocity – occurs about 1 year after thelarche and before menarche
  4. Menarche – typically 2–2.5 years after thelarche, after peak growth has occurred
  5. Axillary hair – develops later in the sequence
  6. Vaginal discharge – may occur just before menarche

Since this girl already has breast and pubic hair, the next expected milestone is peak height velocity.

Incorrect Options:

Vaginal discharge (Option A): May occur just before menarche, but not typically right after thelarche/puberty onset.

Menarche (Option C): Usually occurs about 2 years after breast development starts; not the immediate next milestone.

Axillary hair development (Option D):Comes later, usually after pubic hair is well established and often after menarche.

questions.text:
Given below what is the correct sequence of Damage control surgery?
1. Patient selection
2. Primary exploration
3. ICU care
4. Secondary exploration
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,2,3,4

Explanation: Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is performed in critically ill or severely injured patients to quickly control bleeding and contamination, then allow physiological stabilization before definitive repair.

Sequence:

  • Patient selection – Identify patients who are unstable (acidosis, hypothermia, coagulopathy) and unlikely to survive prolonged surgery.
  • Primary exploration – Abbreviated laparotomy to control hemorrhage (packing, vessel ligation) and contamination (bowel stapling, temporary closure).
  • ICU care – Aggressive resuscitation and correction of acidosis, coagulopathy, and hypothermia.
  • Secondary exploration – Definitive surgical repair after stabilization, usually within 24–48 hours.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has been raised as a girl, has not developed breast tissue, and ultrasound reveals absence of the uterus. Karyotyping shows a 46 XY chromosomal pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 17-hydroxylase deficiency

Explanation:

17α-hydroxylase deficiency is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to a mutation in the CYP17A1 gene.

  • This enzyme has two functions:
    1. 17α-hydroxylase activity – needed for cortisol synthesis.
    2. 17,20-lyase activity – needed for sex steroid synthesis.

When it’s defective, the body cannot produce cortisol or sex steroids (androgens or estrogens) efficiently.

Consequences:

  • Cortisol deficiency → ACTH increases → adrenal hyperplasia.
  • Sex steroid deficiency → lack of androgens in XY → female-like external genitalia; in XX → absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Excess mineralocorticoids (due to shunting into deoxycorticosterone production) → hypertension + hypokalemia.

Key laboratory findings:

  • ↑ ACTH (due to low cortisol)
  • ↑ Mineralocorticoids (DOC, corticosterone)
  • ↓ Renin
  • ↓ Sex steroids (testosterone, estradiol)
    ↑ BP, ↓ K⁺

Incorrect Options:

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) (Option A):

  • 46 XY, testes present → AMH causes uterus absence
  • External genitalia: female
  • Breast development is normal because androgens get aromatized to estrogen (this patient has NO breast development, so AIS is unlikely).

MRKH syndrome (Müllerian agenesis) (Option B):

  • 46 XX (this patient is 46 XY).
  • Breasts develop normally in MRKH, so not matching here.

Swyer syndrome (46 XY gonadal dysgenesis) (Option C):

  • 46 XY but streak gonads, no AMH → uterus present (this patient has absent uterus).

questions.text: During assited vaginal delivery, where is the vacuum device typically applied?

choices.text: At 3 cm behind the anterior fonatnelle
3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

Explanation:

  • In assisted vaginal delivery (vacuum extraction), the optimal placement of the vacuum cup is over the flexion point, this is about 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle along the sagittal suture toward the anterior fontanelle.
  • The flexion point is the ideal spot for achieving maximum flexion of the fetal head, ensuring the smallest presenting diameter (suboccipitobregmatic diameter) passes through the birth canal.
  • Placing the cup here causes the chin to tuck toward the chest, improving descent and minimizing trauma.

Incorrect Options:

3 cm behind the anterior fontanelle (Option A): This is too far forward (over the forehead), promoting deflexion instead of flexion → increases the presenting diameter → more risk of failure.

On the posterior fontanelle (Option B): Cup directly over the posterior fontanelle risks slippage and doesn’t produce optimal head flexion.

Between anterior and posterior fontanelle (Option D): This is vague and not necessarily at the exact flexion point — less effective.

questions.text: What is the co-test in cervical cancer screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPV and PAP smear

Explanation:

Co-testing in cervical cancer screening refers to performing both:

  1. HPV testing – detects high-risk human papillomavirus DNA (especially HPV 16 and 18, which cause ~70% of cervical cancers).
  2. Pap smear (cytology) – examines cervical cells for precancerous or cancerous changes.

HPV testing → very sensitive for detecting the cause (virus) of cervical cancer.
Pap smear → detects cellular changes before they become invasive.
Together, they improve detection rates and reduce the risk of missing early disease.

In many countries, co-testing (HPV + Pap) is recommended every 5 years for women aged 30–65 years if results are negative.

Incorrect Options:

Pap smear and VIA (Option B): VIA (visual inspection with acetic acid) is used in low-resource settings, not the preferred method in settings where HPV testing is available.

HPV and VIA (Option C): skips cytology, so abnormal cells may be missed despite HPV positivity.

Pap smear and colposcopy (Option D): Colposcopy is a follow-up diagnostic tool, not a primary screening test.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for laparoscopic surgery under general anesthesia in a day care setting. Which of the following factors makes him unsuitable for day care surgery?

choices.text: Home is 45 minutes away from the hospital
The surgical procedure is expected to last slightly over 1 hour
No attendant is available at home to care for the patient postoperatively
The patient has had general anesthesia in the past without complications

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - No attendant is available at home to care for the patient postoperatively:

Explanation:

A fundamental requirement for day care surgery with general anesthesia is the presence of a responsible adult.

This person must transport the patient home and provide care for at least the first 24 hours post-surgery.

After general anesthesia, patients have impaired judgment, coordination, and reaction time.

The absence of a caregiver poses a significant safety risk due to the potential for:

  • Falls and other injuries.
  • Delayed reactions to medications.
  • Inability to recognize or appropriately respond to post-operative complications.

Without this support, the patient is unsuitable for discharge to their home.

Incorrect Options:

Home is 45 minutes away from the hospital (Option A): A 45-minute drive is generally considered a reasonable distance for day care surgery. The key is that the patient can return to the hospital in a timely manner if a problem arises.

The surgical procedure is expected to last slightly over 1 hour (Option B): The duration of a procedure is a factor in determining suitability for day care, but a procedure just over an hour is well within the acceptable range for many ambulatory surgical centers.

The patient has had general anesthesia in the past without complications (Option D): This is a positive factor. A history of uncomplicated anesthesia suggests the patient is less likely to have an adverse reaction to the anesthetic agents, making them a more suitable candidate for day care surgery, not less.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for an 8cm chylolymphatic mesenteric cyst?

choices.text: Resection of the cyst along with the adjacent bowel

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Enucleation

Explanation:

  • Chylolymphatic mesenteric cysts are typically benign, well-encapsulated lesions arising from lymphatic malformations in the mesentery. The majority are attached to the mesentery but do not infiltrate the bowel wall, meaning the cyst can be separated from the mesenteric vessels without compromising bowel blood supply.
  • Preferred treatment: Complete enucleation of the cyst while preserving the bowel, to prevent recurrence and avoid unnecessary resection.

Tillaux Triad:

  1. Peri-umbilical swelling
  2. Tillaux sign → swelling moves at right angle to mesentery
  3. Transverse band of resonance

Investigation of choice: Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT)

Types of Mesenteric Cysts

 

Chylolymphatic cyst (most common)

Enterogenous cyst

Origin

Sequestered lymphatic tissue

Sequestered bowel tissue

Wall

Thin

Thick

Fluid

Clear

Turbid

Blood supply

Independent

Shares with bowel

Treatment

Enucleation

Resection + anastomosis

Site distribution:

  • Small intestine → 60%
  • Colon → 40%

Complications:

  • Torsion
  • Rupture
  • Infection
  • Hemorrhage

Aspiration (Option A) – Not definitive; high recurrence/infection risk.

Resection of the cyst along with the adjacent bowel (Option C) – Needed only when the cyst shares vascular supply with the bowel or infiltrates the wall.

Conservative (Option D) – Not appropriate due to risk of enlargement, infection, torsion, or rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to subcutaneous contraceptive implant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Undiagnosed genital bleeding

Explanation:

  • Undiagnosed genital bleeding can be a sign of serious underlying conditions like endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, or structural lesions.
  • Inserting a subcutaneous contraceptive implant without first diagnosing the cause could delay detection and treatment of a potentially dangerous condition.
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria lists it as Category 4 (unacceptable health risk) until the cause is clarified.

Incorrect Options:

Hypertension (Option A): Most progestin-only contraceptives (like implants) do not significantly raise blood pressure. It is safe in most women with controlled hypertension (Category 1–2), though regular monitoring is advised.

Diabetes mellitus (Option B): Progestin-only implants have minimal metabolic impact and are generally safe for diabetic patients, unless there is severe vascular disease.

PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease) (Option C): Implants act systemically, not via the intrauterine route, so they don’t worsen PID risk. The main concern with PID is for intrauterine devices (IUDs), not implants.

questions.text: During general anesthesia, which nerve is commonly monitored using a nerve stimulator to assess neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ulnar nerve:

Explanation:

The ulnar nerve is the standard site for neuromuscular monitoring because:

  1. Muscle Innervation: It innervates the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand. This muscle is highly sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents, and its response accurately reflects the blockade's depth.
  2. Clear Twitch Response: Monitoring the adductor pollicis muscle provides a clear and easily measurable twitch response. This allows anesthesiologists to precisely gauge the degree of muscle paralysis.
  3. Superficial Location: The ulnar nerve is easily accessible at the wrist, making electrode placement simple and reliable.
  4. Assessment of Blockade: It provides a dependable assessment of non-depolarizing blockade, which is crucial for determining the appropriate time for drug administration or reversal.

Incorrect Options:

Radial nerve (Option A) is not typically used for NMB monitoring due to its deeper location and the variable and less reliable responses from the muscles it innervates.

Median nerve (Option C) is generally reserved for somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) monitoring, which is used to assess the function of the spinal cord and somatosensory pathways, rather than neuromuscular blockade.

Tibial nerve (Option D) can be used for monitoring NMB, particularly for lower extremity procedures, but it is less standardized and often provides less reliable data compared to the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A patient under anesthesia is found to be in a “cannot intubate, cannot ventilate” (CICV) scenario. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Perform a cricothyroidotomy:

Explanation:

A "cannot intubate, cannot ventilate" (CICV) scenario is a life-threatening emergency in which both endotracheal intubation and non-invasive ventilation (e.g., with a bag-valve-mask or supraglottic airway) have failed. This situation demands an immediate and decisive response to establish an airway.

  • Immediate Surgical Airway: In a CICV situation, an immediate surgical airway is required to oxygenate the patient and prevent hypoxic brain injury or cardiac arrest. This must be performed as quickly as possible, ideally within 3-5 minutes of declaring the CICV state.
  • Cricothyroidotomy: A cricothyroidotomy is the fastest and most accessible emergency surgical airway technique. It involves making a small incision through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to insert a tube directly into the trachea. Because it is performed at a superficial level and does not require complex dissection, it is the method of choice in this time-critical situation.

Incorrect Options:

Insert nasopharyngeal airway (Option A) is a type of non-invasive airway adjunct that is used for partial airway obstruction. It is ineffective in a complete airway obstruction, which is characteristic of a CICV scenario.

Insert a laryngeal mask airway (Option C) is a supraglottic airway device that should have already been attempted as part of the standard difficult airway algorithm before the declaration of a CICV situation. If it has failed, it is no longer a viable option.

Perform a tracheostomy (Option D) is a surgical procedure to create a more permanent airway. It is a more complex and time-consuming procedure than a cricothyroidotomy and is therefore not the appropriate choice for an emergency, life-threatening situation like CICV.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen after 4 days of cholecystectomy. On USG, it showed a significant collection in RUQ. What will you do further?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. USG-guided aspiration of content

Explanation:

  • The patient presents 4 days post-cholecystectomy with a localized collection in the right upper quadrant on ultrasound. The immediate priority here is diagnosis and therapeutic drainage — aspiration will relieve symptoms, confirm the nature of the fluid (bile, pus, blood), and guide further management. If the aspirated content is bile → further evaluation with MRCP or ERCP can be planned to localize and treat the leak. Aspiration is minimally invasive and avoids unnecessary re-exploration in a stable patient.

Post-Cholecystectomy Collections:

  • Causes: Bile leak (cystic duct stump leak, accessory duct injury), intra-abdominal abscess, hematoma, seroma.
  • Symptoms: Fever, abdominal pain, localized tenderness, distension, jaundice (if major duct injury).
  • Diagnosis:
    • USG: Detects and localizes fluid collection.
    • Aspiration: Confirms content type.
    • MRCP: Maps biliary anatomy if a bile leak is suspected.
    • ERCP: Diagnostic + therapeutic (stenting, sphincterotomy).
  • Surgical anatomy:
    • Calot’s triangle boundaries → Cystic duct (medial), common hepatic duct (lateral), inferior surface of liver (superior).
    • Contents: Cystic artery, cystic lymph node of Lund, connective tissue.

  • Management pathway:
    • USG-guided aspiration.
    • If bile leak → MRCP/ERCP.
    • Persistent leak or large duct injury → surgical repair.

Re-explore laparoscopically (Option A) – Too invasive without knowing the nature of the collection.

Higher antibiotics (Option B) – Won’t resolve a large collection; drainage is required.

MRCP (Option C) – Useful after confirming bile in the aspirate, but here aspiration is the first step.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery develops sudden deranged vitals following a failed attempt at subclavian vein catheterization. On examination, the trachea is shifted to one side and breath sounds are absent on the same side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tension pneumothorax

Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation is a classic triad of signs and symptoms that strongly indicate a tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition that occurs when air enters the pleural space, but cannot escape, causing a one-way valve effect. The key findings are:

  • Tracheal deviation: The trachea is shifted away from the affected side as the increasing pressure in the pleural space pushes the mediastinum to the opposite side.
  • Absent breath sounds: Breath sounds are absent on the affected side due to the complete collapse of the lung.
  • Hypotension and hypoxia: The high intrathoracic pressure compresses the major blood vessels, leading to a significant decrease in venous return, causing hypotension. This also impairs gas exchange, leading to hypoxia.

Incorrect Options:

Bronchospasm (Option A) would present with wheezing and difficulty breathing, but it would not cause tracheal deviation or absent breath sounds.

Pulmonary embolism (Option C) typically presents with sudden-onset tachycardia and hypoxia. While it is a serious complication, it would not lead to absent breath sounds or tracheal deviation. The trachea would remain in a midline position.

Aspiration pneumonitis (Option D) would present with symptoms like crackles, fever, and respiratory distress, but it is not a sudden, acute collapse of the lung that would cause tracheal shift and absent breath sounds.

questions.text: A follow-up patient of GERD on endoscopy was having a nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum, which hormone are you suspecting to be raised?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Gastrin

Explanation:

  • A nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum in a patient with GERD symptoms raises suspicion of a gastrinoma (Zollinger–Ellison syndrome).

Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor → marked acid hypersecretion → severe peptic ulcer disease.
  • Common sites:
    • Duodenum (~70%)
    • Pancreas (~25%)
    • Other sites (~5%) — stomach, lymph nodes.
  • Gastrinoma Triangle:
    • Cystic duct–CBD junction
    • Junction of 2nd & 3rd part of duodenum
    • Neck & body of the pancreas.

  • Associations: MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1) → Gastrinoma + Pituitary adenoma + Parathyroid hyperplasia.
  • Clinical features:
    • Refractory peptic ulcers (often multiple, distal to duodenal bulb)
    • GERD
    • Chronic diarrhea (acid inactivates pancreatic enzymes → malabsorption)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Fasting serum gastrin >1000 pg/mL (very high suspicion)
    • Secretin stimulation test → paradoxical rise in gastrin.
    • Imaging: Endoscopic ultrasound, somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.
  • Treatment:
    • High-dose proton pump inhibitors (acid suppression).
    • Surgical excision if localized.

Inulin (Option B) – Not a hormone; used as a marker for GFR measurement.

VIP (Option C) – Elevated in VIPoma; causes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome), and no duodenal nodules with GERD.

Glucagon (Option D) – Elevated in glucagonoma; presents with necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, and anemia, typically in the pancreas, not the duodenum.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of cesarean section is in labor and has contractions of 3/10, no fetal distress and membranes are intact. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and monitor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and monitor

Explanation:

Artificial rupture of membranes can:

  • Increase endogenous prostaglandin release
  • Strengthen contractions naturally
  • Help labor progress

It allows continued monitoring of fetal heart rate and labor progress without immediately escalating to high-risk interventions.

Since the patient is already in labor with contractions 3 in 10 minutes (mild to moderate frequency), no fetal distress, and membranes intact, we do a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC).

Incorrect Options:

Oxytocin (Option A): In women with prior cesarean, oxytocin should be used with great caution because it increases uterine rupture risk.Before augmenting with oxytocin, simpler and safer measures like ARM are preferred.

Instrumental delivery (Option C): Instrumental delivery is only indicated in the second stage of labor when the cervix is fully dilated, head is low, and there’s a clear indication (e.g., fetal distress, maternal exhaustion). This patient is not yet at that stage.

Repeat cesarean section (Option D): There are no signs of fetal distress or labor arrest that would require an immediate C-section. Since she’s stable, attempting vaginal delivery is reasonable.

questions.text: A neonate has intestines protruding from the abdomen without any external covering. What will be your next line of management?

choices.text: Cover the content with a Silo bag and wait

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Cover the content with a Silo bag and wait

Explanation:

  • A neonate with intestines protruding without any external covering is most likely gastroschisis. In gastroschisis, the bowel is directly exposed to air and amniotic fluid postnatally, making it edematous, thick, and friable. If the abdominal cavity is too small to accommodate the swollen bowel without causing respiratory compromise, primary surgical closure is avoided initially. Instead, the bowel is placed in a sterile silo bag to protect it, prevent fluid loss, and allow gradual reduction of contents into the abdomen over several days, after which definitive closure is performed. This staged approach minimizes the risk of abdominal compartment syndrome and preserves bowel viability.
  • Another gastric defect is an Omphalocele.

Gastroschisis vs Omphalocele:

Feature

Gastroschisis

Omphalocele

Defect location

Right of umbilicus

Through umbilicus

Covering

None (bare bowel)

Peritoneum + amnion sac

Associated anomalies

Rare (~10%)

Common (~60%, esp. cardiac, chromosomal)

Cause

Vascular disruption of the right omphalomesenteric artery

Failure of midgut return & closure

Bowel appearance

Thick, edematous, and inflamed

Normal, within sac

Initial management

Silo bag, staged reduction

Protect sac, repair when stable

Image

Surgical correction (Option A) – Primary closure may cause abdominal compartment syndrome; not preferred if bowel is edematous or the abdominal cavity is small.

Conservative management with higher antibiotics (Option B) – Inadequate; needs urgent protective intervention for bowel.

Cover with NS soaked gauze (Option D) – Temporary measure if silo unavailable, but definitive staged reduction in silo is standard.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child was brought to the EMR 6 hours after a burn and was having 22% BSA burns. On examination, cool extremities, BP - 92/50mmHg, PR - 56 BPM. Urine output since burn episode: 30ml. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Give a bolus of 10 ml/kg/hr

Explanation:

  • The child has burn shock — evidenced by hypotension, bradycardia (late sign in children), cool extremities, and low urine output. In pediatric burns, >15% BSA requires urgent IV fluid resuscitation to prevent progression to multi-organ failure.
  • This patient is 6 hours post-burn, meaning there is already an ongoing deficit that must be corrected promptly. Therefore, an initial bolus: 10 ml/kg of Ringer’s lactate is recommended to restore circulation before calculated maintenance fluids.
  • Colloids are not given early because, during the first 24 hours, capillary permeability is markedly increased → colloids leak into the interstitium → worsen edema. Colloids (e.g., albumin) are generally started after 24 hours.

Burn Fluid Resuscitation:

Formula

Calculation

Notes

Parkland formula

4 ml × body weight (kg) × %BSA burned

Use Ringer’s lactate; give ½ in first 8 hrs (from time of burn), remainder in next 16 hrs

Children

Same as adults, but add maintenance fluids (Holliday–Segar method)

Monitor urine output (goal: 1 ml/kg/hr)

Evans formula

Crystalloids + colloids after 24 hrs

Rarely used now

Brooke formula

2 ml × kg × %BSA + maintenance

Modified approach to reduce over-resuscitation

Nutrition in Burns:

  • Hypermetabolic state → ↑ protein and calorie requirement.
  • Early enteral feeding within 24 hrs reduces infections & maintains gut integrity.
  • Protein: 1.5–2 g/kg/day (children may need up to 3 g/kg/day).
  • Calories: 1.5–2 times basal requirement (can use Curreri formula: 25 kcal × kg + 40 kcal × %BSA burned).
  • Supplement vitamins A, C, and zinc to promote healing.

Colloids in Burns:

  • Avoid in the first 24 hrs due to increased vascular permeability.
  • After 24 hrs, it may be used to maintain plasma oncotic pressure and reduce total crystalloid requirement.
  • Common colloids: albumin, plasma protein fraction.

Give colloid bolus (Option B) – Not indicated in the first 24 hrs; will leak into tissues and worsen edema.

Surgical intervention (Option C) – Definitive management is delayed until the patient is hemodynamically stable.

Give bolus at 30 ml/kg/hr (Option D) – Unsafe; may cause fluid overload, pulmonary edema, and abdominal compartment syndrome.

questions.text: After an RTA patient has severe Maxillofacial trauma with SpO2 80% at room air, and the patient cannot be intubated or ventilated, what should be your immediate step for this?

choices.text: Do suction and again try intubation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Cricothyrotomy

Explanation:

  • In this patient, in whom intubation and ventilation are not possible is known as a “cannot intubate, cannot ventilate” (CICV) scenario → this is a surgical airway emergency.
  • Severe maxillofacial trauma often distorts airway anatomy, making both oral and nasal intubation impossible. In CICV, the fastest and most accessible surgical airway is emergency cricothyrotomy. Although tracheostomy provides a definitive airway, it takes longer and requires a more stable patient; not suitable for immediate life-threatening hypoxia. Cricothyrotomy allows rapid oxygenation within 30–60 seconds.

Cricothyrotomy:

  • Indications:
    1. CICV situations
    2. Severe facial trauma
    3. Upper airway obstruction
    4. Massive facial burns/swelling
  • Landmarks:
    1. Thyroid cartilage
    2. Cricothyroid membrane (between thyroid & cricoid cartilage)
  • Procedure:
    1. Palpate the cricothyroid membrane.
    2. Make a vertical skin incision, a horizontal membrane incision.
    3. Insert a tracheostomy or endotracheal tube.
  • Advantages: Quick, minimal equipment, bypasses upper airway obstruction.
  • Limitations: Should be converted to tracheostomy within 24–72 hrs to prevent subglottic stenosis.

Other surgical airway options in emergencies:

  • Needle cricothyrotomy with jet ventilation: In children <12 years or where surgical cricothyrotomy is risky.
  • Tracheostomy: elective or semi-urgent, not first-line in hypoxic arrest situations.

Tracheostomy (Option B) – Too time-consuming in a rapidly desaturating patient.

ICD insertion (Option C) – For chest trauma/pneumothorax, not airway obstruction.

Do suction and again try intubation (Option D) – Wastes critical seconds; patient already in CICV state.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male was brought to OPD with pain right side testes after being hit by a cricket ball 2 hours back. On examination, severe testicular pain and an absent cremasteric reflex. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. USG Arterial Doppler

Explanation:

The above clinical case of an adolescent male with testicular pain and absent cremasteric reflex is suggestive of testicular torsion. Guidelines recommend color Doppler ultrasound as the first investigation to check testicular blood flow.

USG Arterial Doppler will show:

  • Absent or reduced arterial flow → confirms torsion → immediate surgical exploration.
  • Normal or increased flow → rules out torsion, suggests inflammation.

However, if clinical suspicion is extremely high (classic torsion features), exploration is preferred without delay.

Testicular Torsion:

  • Twisting of the spermatic cord → cuts off arterial supply to the testis → surgical emergency.
  • Peak age: Neonates and adolescents (12–18 years).
  • Causes: Bell-clapper deformity, trauma, sudden movements, or spontaneous.
  • Key clinical signs:
    • Sudden severe unilateral testicular pain
    • High-riding, horizontally oriented testis
    • Absent cremasteric reflex
    • Negative Prehn’s sign (no relief on elevation)
  • Golden period: Salvage rate is best if detorsion is done within 6 hours; irreversible damage after ~12 hours.
  • Treatment: Surgical exploration, detorsion, and bilateral orchidopexy (fixation of both testes).

USG Arterial Doppler in Acute Scrotal Pain:

Feature

Doppler finding

Testicular torsion

Absent/reduced intratesticular arterial flow

Epididymo-orchitis

Increased/normal flow

Torsion appendage

Normal testicular flow, appendage visible as a hyperechoic mass

NSAIDs (Option B) – Only symptomatic; would delay definitive diagnosis.

USG Venous Doppler (Option C) – Venous flow is less reliable than arterial assessment for torsion diagnosis.

Surgical exploration (Option D) – Best for classic torsion presentation; but here, trauma history may lower pretest probability, so Doppler is chosen first.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with multiple episodes of abdominal pain and a history of passing blood in his stools. On examination, he has darkly pigmented spots on his lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Based on the above signs and symptoms, this classic triad is diagnostic of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome (PJS), a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by STK11/LKB1 gene mutation. There is an increased risk for multiple cancers: GI (colon, stomach, pancreas), breast, ovary, cervix, and testes.

Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome (PJS):

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.
  • Gene: STK11/LKB1 tumor suppressor gene mutation (chromosome 19p13.3).
  • Pathology: Multiple hamartomatous polyps (non-neoplastic, but with malignant potential due to genetic instability).
  • Features:
    • Mucocutaneous pigmentation → dark spots on lips, buccal mucosa, fingertips.
      • Pigmentation is due to melanin deposition in the basal cell layer (resembles freckles, but in the mucosa too).

    • Hamartomatous polyps predominantly in the small intestine (especially jejunum).
    • Symptoms: abdominal pain, GI bleeding, intussusception (due to large polyps).
  • Complications:
    • Intussusception (the most common acute presentation in children)
    • GI bleeding → anemia
    • Malignancy risk: GI tract (esp. pancreas), breast, gonadal tumors
  • Management:
    • Symptomatic relief for obstruction/bleeding
    • Endoscopic polypectomy for large polyps
    • Cancer surveillance: colonoscopy, upper GI endoscopy, pancreatic screening

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (Option A) – Hundreds to thousands of adenomatous (not hamartomatous) polyps in the colon, due to APC gene mutation; no mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome (Option C) – Multiple juvenile polyps (hamartomas) in colon/rectum, usually <5 years; no mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Cronkhite–Canada Syndrome (Option D) – Non-hereditary, middle-aged adults; GI polyps + alopecia, skin hyperpigmentation, nail atrophy (but not perioral mucosal pigmentation pattern).

questions.text: A young adult patient presents with a fracture of the neck of the femur. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Internal fixation

Explanation:

The most appropriate management for a femoral neck fracture in a young adult is internal fixation. This method involves surgically inserting screws or a plate to stabilize the fracture while preserving the patient's natural hip joint.

  • Preserving the Femoral Head: Unlike older patients, young adults have a higher potential for the femoral head to heal and maintain its blood supply. Internal fixation is chosen to preserve the native femoral head and joint, which is crucial for a young, active patient.
  • Preventing Complications: The goal is to achieve an accurate reduction and stable fixation to promote healing and reduce the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis (AVN) and nonunion, which are more likely if the fracture is not treated correctly.

Incorrect Options:

External fixation (Option A) is typically used for temporary stabilization in cases of polytrauma or open fractures but is not the definitive treatment for a femoral neck fracture.

Hemiarthroplasty (Option C) involves replacing the femoral head but not the acetabulum. It is primarily reserved for elderly, low-demand patients who are not expected to have a good outcome with internal fixation.

Total hip replacement (Option D) involves replacing both the femoral head and the acetabulum. This is the gold standard for treating arthritic hips or for elderly, active patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, but it is generally avoided in young adults to preserve the native joint for as long as possible.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to EMT with H/o Penetrating chest trauma. On examination, severe tracheal deviation was present. What is the immediate step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Needle decompression

Explanation:

  • History of penetrating trauma, severe tracheal deviation after chest trauma strongly suggests tension pneumothorax.

Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency caused by one-way air entry into the pleural space, leading to:

  • Increased intrathoracic pressure → collapse of the ipsilateral lung → pushes mediastinum away from affected side.
  • Mediastinal shift → compression of the opposite lung and major vessels
  • Obstructive shock → ↓ venous return, ↓ cardiac output

Do NOT wait for imaging like CXR or E-FAST; immediate decompression is required.

Needle decompression → large-bore cannula into the 5th intercostal space (mid-axillary line), followed by ICD (chest tube) placement.

Tension Pneumothorax:

  • Causes: Trauma (blunt/penetrating), barotrauma, mechanical ventilation, rib fractures.
  • Symptoms: Sudden respiratory distress, tachycardia, hypotension, unilateral absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, tracheal deviation away from the affected side, and distended neck veins.
  • Management:
    1. Immediate needle decompression
    2. Intercostal chest drain insertion for definitive management

Chest X-ray (Option B) – Imaging delays life-saving intervention; done after stabilizing the patient.

E-FAST (Option C) – Bedside ultrasound is useful in trauma, but here the diagnosis is clinical, and urgent treatment is the priority.

O₂ support at 100% (Option D) – Oxygen is supportive but will not relieve the life-threatening pressure in the pleural space.

questions.text: A patient presents with a ring-shaped (lytic) lesion in the bone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Brodie's abscess:

Explanation:

Brodie's abscess is a subacute or chronic form of osteomyelitis, a bacterial infection of the bone. It's most commonly found in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly in the tibia.

  • Imaging Features: On an X-ray, it presents as a lytic, ring-shaped lesion surrounded by a thick, reactive sclerotic rim. The central lytic area represents the pus-filled abscess, while the sclerotic rim is new bone formation laid down by the body in response to the chronic infection.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients, often young adults, may experience localized pain that is worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Incorrect Options:

Simple bone cyst (Option B): This is a benign, fluid-filled lesion that appears as a simple, lucent (lytic) area in the bone, without the characteristic sclerotic rim seen in Brodie's abscess

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option C): This is a benign, expansile lesion often described as having a "soap bubble" appearance on imaging. It is filled with blood and has a thin shell of bone. It does not typically have the thick, sclerotic rim of a Brodie's abscess.

 

Osteoid osteoma (Option D): This is a benign bone tumor characterized by a small, radiolucent nidus (the actual tumor) surrounded by a large area of reactive cortical sclerosis. While it has a sclerotic component, the central lytic nidus is typically very small and not ring-shaped.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the child.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Umbilical Hernia

Explanation:

  • The image shows a soft swelling at the umbilicus in a child, which is characteristic of an Umbilical Hernia.

Definition: Protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring due to incomplete closure of the abdominal wall after birth.

Typical presentation in children:

  • Soft bulge at the navel.
  • More prominent when the child cries, coughs, or strains.
  • Usually painless.

Etiology: Common in infants, especially premature babies, due to delayed closure of the umbilical ring.

Prognosis: Most close spontaneously by 2–3 years of age.

Spigelian Hernia (Option B): Occurs along the semilunar line (lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle), not at the umbilicus.

Inguinal Hernia (Option C): Presents as swelling in the groin or scrotum, not at the umbilicus. It is commonly due to a patent processus vaginalis.

Femoral Hernia (Option D): Appears as swelling below the inguinal ligament, more common in adult females.

questions.text: A patient was in a road traffic accident and presented with the following fracture. What type of fracture is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intertrochanteric fracture

Explanation:

The image shows a fracture that occurs in the proximal femur, specifically in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters. This is the definition of an intertrochanteric fracture.

  • Location: This type of fracture is located in the extracapsular region of the hip joint, meaning it is outside the joint capsule. This is an important distinction because the blood supply to the femoral head is typically well-preserved in these fractures, leading to a lower risk of avascular necrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Characteristics: These fractures are often comminuted (broken into multiple fragments) and can have a spiral or oblique pattern. They are common in elderly patients, often resulting from a simple fall.

Incorrect Options:

Subtrochanteric fracture (Option A) occurs below the lesser trochanter, in the shaft of the femur.

Femoral neck fracture (Option C) occurs within the joint capsule (intracapsular) and is located superior to the intertrochanteric region. It is associated with a higher risk of avascular necrosis.

Pubic rami fracture (Option D) is a type of pelvic fracture and is not a fracture of the femur.

questions.text: A child comes after a train accident with stable vitals but a big laceration on the leg. Which triage category does the patient come under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Yellow

Explanation:

  • In disaster triage, the Yellow category means the patient is “Delayed” — they have serious injuries but are not in immediate danger of death and can tolerate some delay before definitive treatment.
  • Stable vitals → no immediate threat to airway, breathing, or circulation.
  • Big laceration on the leg → significant injury requiring medical attention, but not life-threatening right now.
  • The child can be managed after Red category (Immediate) patients are stabilized.

Triage Color Codes:

  1. Red - Immediate (Option A)
    • Life-threatening but treatable injuries needing urgent attention.
    • Examples: airway obstruction, severe bleeding, shock.
  2. Yellow - Delayed (Option B)
    • Serious injuries but stable; treatment can be delayed.
    • Examples: large lacerations, stable fractures, moderate burns.
  3. Green - Minor
    • Walking wounded; minor injuries.
    • Examples: small cuts, abrasions, sprains.
  4. Black - Expectant / Deceased (Option D)
    • No signs of life or injuries incompatible with survival even with care.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the hospital. Parents report a history of a single fall, but X-ray reveals multiple fractures at different stages of healing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Battered baby syndrome

Explanation:

This clinical scenario presents a classic case of non-accidental injury, also known as battered baby syndrome or child abuse. The key red flags are:

  • Inconsistent History: The parents' report of a single, minor fall is inconsistent with the severity and number of fractures. A single fall from a short height is highly unlikely to cause multiple fractures in an infant.
  • Multiple Fractures at Different Stages of Healing: The presence of both new fractures and older, healing fractures on the X-ray is a strong indicator of repeated trauma over time, not a single event.
  • Fracture Patterns: Certain fracture patterns are highly suggestive of abuse, such as metaphyseal corner fractures (also known as "bucket handle" fractures) and posterior rib fractures in an infant.

Incorrect Options:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option A) is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones. While it can cause multiple fractures, it is typically accompanied by other signs, such as blue sclera, a family history of the condition, and a history of fractures from minimal trauma, but not usually from the severe, inconsistent trauma seen in abuse.

Accidental fall (Option B) is ruled out by the discrepancy between the reported history and the X-ray findings. A single fall would not explain multiple fractures in different stages of healing.

Birth trauma (Option D) could cause an acute fracture, such as a clavicle or long bone fracture, but these fractures would all be at the same, acute stage of healing and would be consistent with the delivery process, not multiple fractures at different stages.

questions.text: Which of the following veins are involved in the formation of esophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Left gastric vein

Explanation:

  • Esophageal varices occur due to portal hypertension (commonly from liver cirrhosis).
  • In portal hypertension, blood flow is obstructed in the portal vein, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses.

One important site is lower esophagus, where:

  • Portal circulation: Left gastric vein (drains into portal vein)
  • Systemic circulation: Esophageal veins (drain into azygos vein → superior vena cava)

Increased pressure in the left gastric vein causes dilated submucosal esophageal veins → varices.

Right gastric vein (Option B): Drains the lesser curvature of the stomach. It connects to the portal vein, but not a major contributor to lower esophageal varices.

Left gastroepiploic vein (Option C): Drains the greater curvature of the stomach into the splenic vein (portal system). It is not involved in esophageal portosystemic anastomosis.

Right gastroepiploic vein (Option D): Drains into the superior mesenteric vein (portal system). It has no role in esophageal varices.

questions.text: Injury to which part causes difficulty in dorsiflexion of the foot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – B:

Explanation:

The x-ray shows nerves labelled around the knee. B is pointing to the common peroneal nerve.

  • Function of the Common Peroneal Nerve: The common peroneal nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the lower leg. Specifically, it branches into the deep and superficial peroneal nerves. The deep peroneal nerve innervates the tibialis anterior muscle, which is the primary muscle responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot (lifting the foot upward).
  • Clinical Significance: Injury to the common peroneal nerve, which is common due to its superficial location around the fibular head, results in the inability to dorsiflex the foot. This condition is known as foot drop, where the foot hangs down and the patient has to lift their leg high to avoid dragging their toes while walking.

Incorrect Options:

A- Sciatic nerve (Option A) is the main nerve of the leg. An injury to this nerve would cause much more widespread weakness, affecting both dorsiflexion and plantarflexion, as well as the hamstring muscles.

C- Tibial nerve (Option C) innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the lower leg, which are responsible for plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward). An injury to this nerve would cause difficulty in plantarflexion.

D- Deep peroneal nerve (Option D) is a terminal branch of the common peroneal nerve. While an injury to this specific branch would cause foot drop, the injury at the level of the common peroneal nerve (B) is a more common site of injury.

questions.text: An elderly woman involved in a road traffic accident presents with difficulty in breathing and altered mental status. D-Dimer is elevated. X-ray findings are suggestive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fat embolism

Explanation:

The patient's presentation following a road traffic accident is highly suggestive of a fat embolism syndrome. This condition occurs when fat globules from the bone marrow are released into the bloodstream after a long bone fracture, traveling to the lungs and brain. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

  • Respiratory Distress: This is the most common symptom, typically occurring 24-72 hours after the trauma. The fat emboli obstruct the pulmonary capillaries, leading to hypoxia and respiratory failure. The chest X-ray often shows bilateral patchy infiltrates, mimicking acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), as seen in the image provided.
  • Neurologic Changes: These can range from altered mental status to confusion, agitation, and even coma, as the fat emboli affect the cerebral circulation.
  • Petechial Rash: A characteristic, but not always present, rash of tiny red spots on the chest, neck, and axilla is a classic finding.

An elevated D-dimer is a non-specific finding that can be seen in both fat embolism and pulmonary embolism, as it indicates a breakdown of a clot. However, the combination of respiratory distress and neurological changes following a long bone fracture (common in road traffic accidents) makes a fat embolism the most likely diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Gas gangrene (Option A) is a severe bacterial infection that would present with crepitus (a crackling sensation under the skin) and a foul-smelling discharge, not the respiratory and neurological symptoms described.

Infection (Option C) would typically present with fever and leukocytosis, which are not the primary features of this acute post-traumatic event.

Pulmonary embolism (Option D) is a similar condition but lacks the characteristic petechial rash and is less likely to cause the specific neurological changes associated with fat embolism. While a D-dimer would be elevated, the clinical picture points more strongly to fat embolism.

questions.text: A patient presents with the fracture shown in X-ray. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this type of fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radial nerve

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a spiral fracture of the midshaft humerus. This type of fracture is notoriously associated with injury to the radial nerve, which runs in close anatomical proximity to the bone at this specific location.

  • Anatomical Proximity: The radial nerve courses through the spiral groove (or radial groove) on the posterior aspect of the humerus. This close relationship makes it highly vulnerable to trauma during a fracture of the midshaft.
  • Clinical Presentation: An injury to the radial nerve typically presents with wrist drop, which is the inability to extend the wrist and fingers. This is a result of the nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the forearm. The incidence of radial nerve palsy in these fractures is approximately 10-20%.

Incorrect Options:

Median nerve (Option A) is located more medially in the arm and is rarely injured in a midshaft humeral fracture.

Ulnar nerve (Option C) runs along the medial epicondyle of the humerus and is most commonly injured in fractures of that region, not the midshaft.

Axillary nerve (Option D) is located more proximally, around the surgical neck of the humerus, and is most often injured in proximal humeral fractures or shoulder dislocations.

questions.text: Which ligament is tested in the following test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior cruciate ligament

Explanation:

The image depicts the anterior drawer test, a clinical maneuver used to assess the integrity of the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL). The test is performed by:

  • Flexing the patient's knee to 90 degrees.
  • Stabilizing the patient's femur with one hand.
  • Pulling the tibia forward with the other hand.

Incorrect Options:

Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) (Option B) is tested using the posterior drawer test, where the examiner pushes the tibia backward.

Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) (Option C) is assessed with the valgus stress test, which involves applying a force to the outside of the knee to test for gapping on the medial side.

Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL) (Option D) is assessed with the varus stress test, which involves applying a force to the inside of the knee to test for gapping on the lateral side.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought for a routine check-up. Which of the following developmental milestones is most likely to be present at this age?

choices.text: Creeps well on hands and knees

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Creeps well on hands and knees

Explanation:

  • By 9 months, most infants develop good gross motor skills such as creeping (moving on hands and knees) and pulling to stand. They also typically have a crude pincer grasp, respond to their name, and show stranger anxiety.
